general.headline: Senior Lawyer at Clayton Utz
general.description:
I am an employment  lawyer acting for private and public entities across a variety of sectors, including the health, insurance, government, education, construction, finance, transport, and agricultural industries. I have experience assisting employers understand their obligations under employment, industrial, workplace safety, and equal opportunity laws. 

I represent clients in a variety of commercial litigation matters. This includes work on unfair dismissal, adverse action, discrimination, and common law claims.

My practice includes drafting workplace policies, employment agreements and enterprise agreements and providing advice with regard to termination of employment, including assisting employers in managing workplace performance and misconduct, disciplinary procedures, restructuring and redundancy. I also assist clients with enterprise bargaining and award interpretation.

I also have experience assisting clients in response to safety incidents and providing occupational health and safety compliance advice. I assist clients in defence of prosecutions by workplace regulators and in the management of the coronial investigation and inquest process.

I have also advised my clients on corporate governance (conduct of meetings, policies and charters including board charter, securities trading, remuneration, diversity and privacy policies), stakeholder and shareholder management, and general commercial matters.

general.headline: Legal Counsel at EY
general.description:
Licensed to practice law in California; and England and Wales.  

I am an experienced attorney specializing in technology, IT, and related consulting services.  I have recently relocated to Sydney, Australia, and was previously employed by Dassault Systèmes, the 3DEXPERIENCE Company, providing software applications and services designed to support companies' innovation processes.  Dassault Systèmes brings value to over 200,000 customers of all sizes, in all industries, in more than 140 countries.  

I have enjoyed a high level of autonomy and responsibility as a member of the legal team in delivering a diverse array of corporate legal services across the business, including: the development, preparation, drafting and negotiation of complex, multi-million Pound Sterling, Euro, and US Dollar commercial transactions involving software and related professional services; being a strategic member of the M&A team for both the due diligence of target companies as well as the subsequent integration of acquired companies; support of R&D assisting in US and European data privacy compliance, supplier contracts, in-licensing of technology, source code licensing, and royalty agreements; and general legal department support, including litigation, partner, reseller and distributor agreements.

general.headline: Lawyer at Ashurst
general.description:
Achal is a lawyer in the Infrastructure Projects team at Ashurst (Sydney).  Ashurst's Infrastructure practice in Sydney has recently advised the NSW Government on major infrastructure projects such as the Sydney Light Rail and the WestConnex Project.  

Achal has experience in drafting, developing and reviewing contractual arrangements in the form of Project Deeds, Design & Construct Deeds, Construction Deeds, Managing Contractor Contracts (Australian Standards and otherwise), Interface Agreements and the like.  Achal also has experience in dealing with large scale contractor procurement processes, including legal and commercial evaluation of tenderers. 

Achal's recent work has been focused upon the construction law work streams of these various projects.  For example, over the course of 2015, Achal has worked closely with the procurement team at the WestConnex Delivery Authority on various aspects of Stage 2 of the WestConnex Program of Works.  This has included:
- preparing, developing and finalising the Construction Deed for the King Georges Road Interchange Upgrade;
- drafting, developing and finalising a Managing Contractor Contract for the carrying out of preparatory works at the St Peters Interchange site; and
- running a large scale contractor procurement (including legal and commercial evaluation of three tenderers) for the New M5 Main Works.

Achal has also previously acted for Ausgrid on the drafting and development of certain electricity cabling works contracts that have required Ausgrid to engage and negotiate with property developers.

Current and previous clients include Government entities such as:
- Ausgrid;
- Transport for NSW;
- RMS;
- WestConnex Delivery Authority; and
- Sydney Motorway Corporation.

Major project experience includes:
- Sydney CBD and South East Light Rail Project; and
- WestConnex - Stage 2.
     - King Georges Road Interchange Upgrade
     - St Peters Interchange Preparatory Works
     - New M5 Main Tunnel Works

general.headline: Regulatory Strategy Adviser at nbn™ Australia
general.description:
I am a Regulatory Strategy Adviser at nbn. The Regulatory Team is part of the wider Strategy team. My team focuses on supporting the wider business to achieve its goals within the regulatory framework and to work with key stakeholders to influence that regulatory framework.

From 2012 - 2017 I was a  lawyer at Clayton Utz  in the Corporate / M&A / Capital Markets team and also had experience in Financial Services and Commercial Litigation.

I was also heavily involved in the Clayton Utz Pro Bono program and the Community Connect Committee which focuses on the impact Clayton Utz can have in the wider community. In the past I have been a co-coordinator of the Daystar Literacy Buddies Program and actively involved in fundraising for the National Breast Cancer Foundation and the Ovarian Cancer Research Foundation.

I also have a passion for sport and have a media company called 'Ladies who' which encourages women to get involved in conversations about sport through various spin-offs including 'Ladies who League', 'Ladies who Legspin', 'Ladies who Lineout', 'Ladies who W-League' and 'Ladies who Leap'.

I am also recognised as an advocate for women in sport and write for several major publications including NRL.com and the Roar. My weekly podcast ('Ladies who League' in the winter and 'Ladies who Legspin' in the summer) is also part of the ABC Grandstand family. 

I have strong relationships across the Australian sporting landscape, particularly in rugby league.

I am also a Secretary and Director of the LBW Trust, a mentor in the Western Sydney Wanderers W-League Mentoring Program and an ambassador for the Full Stop Foundation.

jobs.description:
Violence against women and children is completely unacceptable in any context. Unfortunately we still live in a world where gendered violence is still a problem our society is dealing with.

As a person who is passionate about gender equality and who truly believes in the importance of respect, I am so proud to work with an organisation like the Full Stop Foundation which has such a vital role in raising awareness about violence against women, and educating and supporting our communities until sexual assault and domestic violence are completely eradicated.

We all have a role to play and I stand with the Full Stop Foundation to help create a more equal and tolerant world.

The LBW Trust provides support to economically disadvantaged students in developing, cricket playing countries to help them complete their tertiary or vocational education.

I am so proud to work with this organisation and in particular, sit on the Women for Change Committee.

In March 2016 I was asked to be an expert contributor on prominent sports website the
      Roar.  I join other experts like Andrew Demetriou, Anthony Minichello, Debbie Spillane,
      Lisa Sthalekar and Melinda Farrell and write a weekly article on rugby league and
      
      another on women's sport.

I started Ladies who League in June 2013 to encouraging women to get involved in
      conversations about sport and it has grown into a thriving media company of which I
      
      am very proud.

general.headline: Partner at HWL Ebsworth Lawyers
general.description:
Hong-Viet is a financial services regulatory lawyer with broad experience gained both in private practice and in-house. 

Her experience includes advising financial services providers (including those in the wealth management, retail banking, superannuation and insurance industries) on a range of matters that affect those providers. This includes:
- advising in relation to the establishment and structuring of financial services entities and products, including in respect of licensing, authorisations and obligations arising under Corporations Act, Banking Act, Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, Insurance Act and Life Insurance Act
- advising in respect of regulatory compliance, including in respect of financial services laws, anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing laws, consumer banking and margin lending, insurance laws, privacy, payment systems and consumer protection
- advising in respect of ongoing obligations, product and services disclosure, and ongoing compliance and risk management
- drafting and negotiating distribution documents, and joint venture and alliance arrangements
- advising on potential breaches of laws (including the obligation to provide breach reports to ASIC and/or APRA, and providing guidance on regulatory engagement strategy)
- due diligence and advice on the sale of financial services businesses and entities, and
- reviewing and amending standard form consumer contracts for compliance with the unfair contract terms regime.

Hong-Viet also has experience dealing with regulators, including ASIC, APRA and AUSTRAC.

Her in-house experience includes working at BT Financial Group, Zurich Insurance Group (HK) and ING (now OnePath). She has also undertaken secondments at the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Suncorp, Westpac and Macquarie Bank.

general.description:
Gillian advises clients on trade mark availability and/or registration in Australia and Papua New Guinea, including challenging trade marks, and plays an active role in risk assessments in connection with important product launches of her clients. 

Her clients include high profile consumer brand multinational corporations, one of which has the distinction of being the largest trade mark owner in the world.  Other key clients include an international group of companies which operates wholly owned and franchised restaurants under major brands, a U.S. corporation owning a portfolio of prestige and well known cosmetics and beauty care brands, a world leader in enterprise software, a leading supplier of technology, integrated project management and information solutions in the oil and gas industry worldwide, an established food brand licensing corporation as well as a institutional Australian broadcaster and a U.S. leading retailer. 

Gillian manages clients' portfolios of trade mark rights in numerous countries, including assisting in registration and disputes. She represents clients in trade mark opposition proceedings in Australia and assists in the enforcement of trade mark rights, and negotiates and drafts agreements relating to the use or sale of trade marks. Gillian advises on other aspects of intellectual property law, including passing off, misleading and deceptive conduct, designs, copyright, domain names and patents.

jobs.companyName: Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry
jobs.description:
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry strives to make Australia a great place to do business. 

We represent more than 300,000 businesses of all sizes, across all industries and all parts of the country. We speak on behalf of the business sector to government and the community, fostering a culture of enterprise and supporting policies that keep Australia competitive. We also represent Australian business in international forums.

Our membership comprises the state and territory chambers of commerce and dozens of national industry associations. Individual businesses can also get involved through our Business Leaders Council.

The business specialises in fundraising, media, government relations, event
      
      management, networking and marketing.

GCA's objectives are to launch careers through intellectually robust, industry
      recognised and government accredited courses at the vocational and higher education
      
      levels, which produce work-ready graduates.

The Estia Foundation is a Christian organisation - an initiative of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of Australia. Our President and Patron is His Eminence Archbishop Stylianos, Primate of the Greek Orthodox Church in Australia. The Estia Foundation's CEO is Father Angelo Alifierakis, who is responsible for all of Estia's operations and services.

The Estia Foundation is a non-profit organisation that relies on donations and State Government funding to provide its valuable services to the community.

Staff and volunteers of Estia are dedicated to helping young adults who have an intellectual and/or physical disability to help them reach their full potential, to integrate and be a valued member of society and to participate in everyday activities that they would otherwise not have been able to do. These young adults are people of many talents - many abilities and are not to be underestimated by any means.

Provided business contacts, networks and government relations advice to the Chief
      
      Executive Officer of the Asian Cup and the senior executives of the FFA.

Representing and advocating for its 1,700 pubs and 150 five, four and three star
      accommodation hotels members across NSW. An industry that employs 100,000
      people, sponsors 75,000 live music acts annually, produces more than 2.5million meals
      
      weekly and donates $25million directly to charities annually throughout the state.

Formed in 1995, Roses Only is part of a family owned business that brings together 45 years of retail and floristry experience. Now Australia’s leading floral retailer, we offer a wide range of exquisitely boxed long stemmed roses, gerberas, lilies tulips and variety of mixed seasonal flowers, in addition to superb floral arrangements and bouquets, accompanied by fine French champagne, premium red and white wines, teddy bears and chocolates.

Hyro is focused purely on Digital Services across Internet, mobile, and interactive TV
      channels; from the user's screen to the back-end systems. Hyro's enterprise-wide
      
      approach provides all necessary services for its clients to attract customers.

general.headline: Director/Principal Costs Lawyer at graham + bull
general.description:
I am the Director and Principal Costs Lawyer at graham + bull - a boutique firm of specialist costs consultants, costs assessors, and costs lawyers with its offices located on the CBD fringe in Brisbane, Melbourne, and on the Sunshine Coast. I have practised exclusively in the area of legal costs since 1996 and I commenced my practice, grahamcosts, in 2001 with the aim of providing legal and forensic costing expertise to the legal, accounting, and insolvency industries, and on 1 January, 2016 I commenced a new firm, graham + bull, practising in partnership with Raymond Bull, costs assessor, costs lawyer, and litigator up until 23 December 2016. In September 2017 Luke Short, costs assessor, joined the team at graham + bull. The firm continues to operate as graham + bull, collaborating with other costs lawyers, and with the assistance of consultants, from time to time, as required.

The firm’s focus is on building and establishing an ongoing and long-term relationship with our clients where we accommodate all of their legal and forensic costing requirements. Our engagement ensures that our clients maintain absolute transparency in their billing processes, together with access to specialist expertise to ensure optimum recovery of costs for their clients.

general.headline: Barrister at New Chambers
general.description:
Kate has practiced as a barrister in Sydney and throughout Australia since 1998. She was appointed Senior Counsel in 2012. Her areas of practice are employment, discrimination, human rights, professional conduct, international law and public law.

Kate works with her clients to achieve effective resolutions of complex legal and interpersonal disputes.

Kate is a Senior Fellow with the Faculty of Law at Monash University in Melbourne. She teaches a range of human rights and international law subjects in the LLM / JD program.

Further information: www.kateeastman.com

jobs.description:
Senior Fellow, Law Faculty.  Teaching a range of courses in the LLM/SJD Program
      

    •	Overview of International Human Rights Law,
      

    •	International Human Rights and Women’s Rights,
      

    •	Human Rights Advocacy,
      

    •	Victorian Charter of Rights,
      

    •	Children’s Rights in Australian Law
      

    •	Children’s Rights in International Law

Kate regularly appears in the Federal Court, Federal Circuit Court, Fair Work Commission, Industrial Relations Commission and State/Territory tribunals for trials and appeals in matters arising under the Fair Work Act, Industrial Relations Act (NSW) and all Federal/State/Territory discrimination laws. She appears for individuals, Commonwealth, State and Territory governments and agencies, for multi-national and Australian ASX 200 corporations, partnerships and small business in a range of matters including internal compliance audits, internal grievance and disciplinary procedures, investigations, mediation, advisory work and litigation.  A list of all appearances can be provided.

Kate has 25 years experience in working in all aspects of discrimination law (employment, services, banking, insurance, sport, education, transport and media). This includes a specialist practice in sexual harassment, bullying and vilification

general.headline: Barrister
general.description:
Admitted to the Bar in 1989. John has practised almost exclusively in personal injury work since 1989. He has been a member of Hargrave Chambers since 1995.

John practices in causes of action arising in New South Wales, the ACT and Queensland. He regularly appears in the following jurisdictions:-
  •  New South Wales Supreme Court
  •  New South Wales District Court
  •  ACT Supreme Court.
  •  NSW Motor Vehicle Claims Assessment Resolution Service
  •  NSW Worker Compensation Commission
  •  Administrative Appeals Tribunal

His forensic strengths are in advocacy, assimilation of facts and immediate identification of the critical issues of a dispute. He acts extensively for plaintiffs, but also insurers, particularly in relation to negligence claims. John has particular expertise in drafting complicated pleadings and schedules. He is client friendly and known for his ability to assimilate complex instructions and respond rapidly with tactics and strategy including pre-emptive remedies when required.

John is an advocate of great experience who has significant experience of personal injury claims, including complex road accident claims, workers compensation, and group litigation. He is experienced at acting for claimants over the whole range of matters including fatal accident litigation, brain damage, spinal injury, amputation and other high value claims including cases of injury of maximum severity, psychiatric damage, and injury to children. John has experience in health and safety, employer's liability, serious industrial accidents, explosions, fires, manual handling, repetitive strain injury and workplace accidents, occupational stress and bullying, occupier's liability claims and sporting injuries.

His practice is focused on:
•  Personal Injury Negligence claims
•  Workers Compensation 
•  Motor vehicle claims.
•  Compensation to Relatives Claims

general.headline: LAW at University of Sydney (LPAB)
general.description:
Armstrong Legal is a personal services law firm limited to defence criminal law, family law and contested estates. I am one of two managing partners and head of the criminal law division.

We work with people who find themselves having made the wrong decisions or find themselves a victim of circumstances and have to answer for their actions before the criminal courts. We are difference because of the value we put on the development of a team approach with our clients, no judgement, no rushing and certainly half way measures. The client provides the instructions and we provide the guidance. As managing partner, client satisfaction is incredibly important to me. I strive to ensure my team provides the best service possible all the time. As a result, we enjoy an exceedingly high level of highly satisfied clients.

Importantly, we are unlike other law firms in our areas of practice because we monitor our matters through ISO Standard Law 9000 and every client is asked to grade the service we provide. 

Should you require our services, the criminal law team, in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane or Canberra, stand ready to assist you. If the response you receive is not what you hoped for, I want to know.

general.description: Nicki is a barrister and a passionate advocate for access to justice, innovative dispute resolution and therapeutic justice.  She leads a multi-disciplinary team to deliver education in Law and Medicine.  Nicki has experience in policy, strategic planning, governance, compliance,  work flow and project management.

jobs.jobTitle: Masters of Law Innovation Agile Team member
jobs.description:
Nicki brings legal practice experience (barrister and former solicitor) and cross faculty
      academic experience (18 years of teaching in Law and Medicine in undergraduate and
      post graduate programs) to this multidisciplinary agile team developing innovative
      
      Masters programs for lawyers and beyond!

As a university lecturer Nicki developed comprehensive knowledge in criminal law and evidence, torts and civil procedure and advanced her interest in medico-legal ethics. Nicki also developed drafting skills in the very practical teaching of pleadings. Nicki was awarded a teaching award in 2008, and consistently receives excellent student feedback. She has excellent oratory skills and a well developed ability to explain complex concepts simply to an informed audience. Nicki produces very accessible summaries and flowcharts which are greatly appreciated by students.

RECENT LECTURES
"Choice of forum - Victorian Civil Litigation"
“Enclosure as a method of sexual penetration”, 
“Dishonesty in property offences: where’s the moral oblique?”, 
“Entrepreneurial lawyering and class actions” 
“Dead Calm: Weissensteiner and the Accused’s right to silence”.
"Suspended sentences - like Suspended coffee but less charitable"
"Boundary blurring in 2013 Medical and Allied health"

Nicki is available to advise and appear in all areas of Health law including:
      guardianship, medical negligence, professional regulation, personal injuries (Workcover
      and common law), coronial inquests, and Criminal law including: hearings, pleas, trials
      
      and appeals.

Nicki is a mediator with a growing passion for online dispute resolution.  F2F, B2B, ODR

      privacy issues, breaches of contract and sale of goods.

•	Designing, managing, writing and implementing a compliance programme for Southern Healthcare Network
•	Appearing for patients,  health care networks and  medical practitioners before the Guardianship Board of Victoria, the Medical Board of Victoria and VCAT in the review of Mental Health Review Board decisions

general.description:
I am a solutions focused in-house lawyer with expertise in the restructuring, workouts and insolvency area. 
 
At NAB, I work with internal stakeholders to manage risk and reputation, delivering proactive, practical, legal advice to NAB in navigating the restructuring and recoveries processes.  I bring a holistic, collaborative, approach; engaging with key stakeholders; working with in-house colleagues (in Perth and Nationally); managing external legal providers; overseeing enforcement steps and litigation; and supporting training and learning opportunities. 

Before joining NAB, I enjoyed nearly 10 years with King & Wood Mallesons, where I advised lenders, insolvency practitioners and corporate clients in a range of distressed debt scenarios.  My experience includes complex workouts, enforcement and insolvency administrations across various industry sectors (resources, property, banking, construction and retail).  I also acted for corporate clients in conducting significant commercial litigation, both in banking and other (non-banking) commercial disputes.

general.description:
Successful, resourceful and results driven National Operations and Facilities professional with over 12 years’ experience in managing large commercial/professional services assets with budgets in excess of $10 Million and multi-million dollar capital and project budgets.

With extensive experience in facility and contract management, occupancy/space planning and measurement, project delivery, workplace transformation and relocation management, I am accustomed to working in complex, fast paced demanding environments, managing the expectations of multiple senior stakeholders. 

As a ‘hands on’ leader, I enjoy working within a team oriented environment where employee and company values are closely aligned, and the primary focus is on working with and leading a team that are committed to delivering on corporate goals and objectives.

Recent accomplishments include working on KPMG's Workplace of the Future program across three states, Adelaide, Sydney and Melbourne

general.headline: Concierge at KPMG Barangaroo, Sydney, Australia
Food and Beverage Coordinator at KPMG Australia
Property Portfolio Management | Facilities Management | ​Large Scale Agile Project Management helping to build workplaces of the future
general.description:
I am a senior Property Portfolio and Facilities manager who is driven to build agile workplaces for the future.  My speciality is in designing, delivering and managing innovative and practical workplace strategies to drive business objectives, deepen workplace engagement and foster effective connections between key stakeholders.

From 2013 - 2017 I was the National Corporate Real Estate Services and Projects lead at KPMG. As Head of Workplace Services I was responsible for lease portfolio management, project management, acquisitions, property and change management nationally.

Among my key accomplishments I successfully managed KPMG’s largest, most expensive and most culturally influential property program in 25 years. I managed the national team (30 staff and numerous contractors) that implemented the firm’s ambitious Workplace of the Future project for 5000 staff, creating industry-leading agile workplaces at the iconic Lendlease development at Barangaroo in Sydney, the Walker Towers at Docklands in Melbourne, and also in Parramatta, Wollongong, Perth, Adelaide and Brisbane. The new offices totalled around 65,000 square-metres, generated overwhelmingly positive responses from partners, managers, staff and clients alike, received widespread attention from design media, and opened up new ways for KPMG to work, entertain and interact with clients.

jobs.description:
Martin commenced as the Chief Executive Officer of Spotless in November 2015.  He leads a team of 36,000 employees who provide services that are essential to businesses across Australia and New Zealand.  He is driving a strategy reset that embraces growth, customer centricity, a high performance culture and brand and innovation.  This progressive change throughout the business will benefit customers, employees and investors.

His dynamic approach, supported by the strong management team and Board, will see growth in the integrated solutions provided by over 100 service lines.  The breadth of Spotless' capability includes asset maintenance and management, catering and hospitality, cleaning, utility support services, facility management, heating ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC), mechanical and electrical services, laundry services and security and alarm services.  Spotless had an annual turnover of $3.1B in FY16.

Martin was a Partner in the KPMG audit practice with over 23 years auditing, accounting and transactions experience. He was the Lead Partner on large public company accounts with global operations and was regularly involved in prominent capital market transactions. Martin advised a broad range of companies across most industry segments. After starting his career working solely with banking and finance clients, Martin broadened his industry focus to include industrial markets and consumer markets and in recent years has focused predominantly on the transportation and mining sectors.

Experience in the following sectors:
Transportation
Road rail and infrastructure
Aviation
Energy & Natural resources
Leasing and Corporate Treasury
Consumer Markets

general.headline: Director, Transformation Services
general.description:
A senior executive with 20 years of experience managing and leading change, including development of and executing against growth strategies with clients, in professional services, banking and finance. I have a proven ability to win work to drive revenue growth and develop service solutions for clients that are focused on delivering value and meeting their needs.   
More recently I work with large multinational and Australian based clients across all industries to bring industry-leading practice to the transformation of their tax functions. I work with a highly-skilled team of solution architects, data scientists, technology and tax specialists, in the development of tailored tax function transformation solutions for clients. This involves a methodical data-driven approach to understanding clients’ tax systems, processes and specific compliance requirements with a view to transforming their resource and operating models, data and technology roadmaps and governance and control frameworks, for greater efficiency, accuracy and insight. 
I joined KPMG Australia in 2005, beginning my career in Audit before leading the Markets and Growth team. As the Chief Operations Officer for Tax, I led the implementation of the operational transformation of the KPMG Australia Tax business, including the centralisation of delivery of all tax compliance through the KPMG Delivery and Data Excellence Centre. 
I hold a Bachelor of Commerce and Economics from the University of Queensland and am a member of the Australian Society of Certified Practicing Accountants (CPA) since 2000. In my spare time, I am kept busy by four children and an active Sydney lifestyle that includes competitive running, swimming and lifesaving. I am the Club Secretary for Kincoppal Rose Bay Aquatics Swimming Club and sits on the Board of the Eastern Suburbs Rugby Union Club.

general.headline: Research Assistant | Centre for Transformative Work Design
general.description:
Siobhan is a provisional psychologist with near 4 years' experience in Management Consulting in the People and Change service line within KPMG, working with clients across public and private sector groups to effect meaningful and sustainable change. Siobhan has a passion for the people side of change, and for developing solutions to enhance employee wellbeing, performance and motivation.

Siobhan has extensive experience working with clients to develop change management strategies to support large-scale transformational change arising from new operating models, technology or system change, organisational restructures, and cultural challenges. 

Siobhan's experience developing solutions to complex people challenges has developed her skills in:
- Behavioural Change Management
- Stakeholder Engagement
- Strategic Communications
- Leadership Development
- Project Management
- Diversity and Inclusion strategies
- Workshop facilitation

jobs.description:
Working on a number of organisational psychology research projects focused on work
      
      redesign to improve job satisfaction, mental health, well-being, and performance.

Siobhan works in the People & Change division of Management Consulting. The People and Change team work with clients across public and private sector groups to navigate transformational change and convert the potential of an organisations' people into financial performance and market value.

Their service offerings fall into 5 areas: Behavioural Change Management, Organisation Design for Performance, Human Resource Optimisation, Talent Management and Workforce Optimisation.

Siobhan was employed in a 3-week vacation program in the Business Performance
      Services division at KPMG in her penultimate year at UWA. After the completion of her
      vacation program, Siobhan was offered a full-time position commencing in 2015 in the
      
      People and Change service line.

Siobhan worked for organisational psychology firm People and Workplace Engagement whilst she was studying at university to compliment her degree. Her role involved interpreting various psychometric assessments and assisting in the development of psychological profiles for clients. Through working alongside experienced organisational psychologists, Siobhan gained valuable knowledge in leadership coaching, psychological profiling, and recruitment and selection strategies.

schools.degree: Bachelor of Science (Hons) / Bachelor of Commerce
schools.description: Bachelor of Science (BSc) with First Class Honours in Psychology/Bachelor of Commerce (BCom)Siobhan completed a double degree of Science and Commerce in 2014 majoring in Psychology, Human Resource Management and Marketing. She achieved first class honours in Psychology for her dissertation on work design.

general.headline: At 350.org Australia working to build a movement to demand climate change action
general.description:
My experience is in people and project management, strategy development and communications across a range of eco and social issues, particularly climate change and marine protection. I am CEO of 350.org in Australia working to build a movement to stop new fossil fuels and rapidly reduce greenhouse emissions. I have worked in Australia, the United Kingdom and the United States in senior management roles for Greenpeace International, The Body Shop internationally, and as a consultant to a range of companies, organisations and government projects including the Antarctic Ocean Alliance, Greenpeace in Australia, China the US and internationally, The Climate Group, Planet Ark, The Climate Institute, The Green Building Council of Australia, Climate Friendly, Ecos Corporation and NSW Government programs the Building Sustainability Index (BASIX) and Sustainable Energy Development Authority (SEDA). I am proud to be on the board of Green Music Australia and was a previous board member of Greenpeace Australia Pacific and a founding committee member for Human Rights Watch Australia.

Specialties: Environment, climate change and social/human rights strategy, communications and marketing, project and team management, fundraising, facilitation, team planning and evaluation.

jobs.description:
350.org is building a movement to address the climate crisis and to stop expansion
      and subsidies of polluting fossile fuels. in Australia we are working to raise awareness
      about plans to greatly expand coal development and exports nationally and in
      particular near the Great Barrier Reef in Queensland and to encourage divestment
      
      from new coal and gas projects.
http://www.greenmusic.org.au/

The Antarctic Ocean Alliance (AOA) is working internationally to establish a network of designated marine protected areas and no-take reserves in the Antarctic – the most comprehensive regime of its kind on the planet. With such a network in place, key Antarctic ocean habitats and wildlife would be protected from human interference. The AOA team is based in Australia, NZ, China, Korea, the UK and Europe and focused on ensuring CCAMLR delivers on its committment to protect critical Southern Ocean habitats
Independant chair assessing GBCA projects

Editor and then Editor-in-Chief of one of Australia's leading environmental magazines
      
      covering issues in Australia and internationally.

I specialise in project management, consulting, strategy development, communications and evaluating for a number of organisations working on environmental and social issues. I am and have worked with Planet Ark, the Make Poverty History campaign, Pew Environment Group, Greenpeace China supporting its review of the green aspects of the Beijing Olympic Games, The Climate Group, The Climate Institute, Low Energy Systems and Services (LESS), Greenpeace Australia Pacific, US and international, Ecos and other clients.

I worked with founder Joel Flemming to develop communications and marketing for
      Climate Friendly in its early years of providing the highest possible quality carbon
      
      credits from renewable energy projects to customers in Australia and around the world.

Contributing writer to Conde Nast Traveler, Gourmet Traveller, an on-line review
      website linked to Crikey, Bootsnall and a range of other outlets in Australia and
      
      internationally.

The Social Value & Intangibles Review is a quarterly international magazine, published in multiple languages and edited by the Centre for Citizenship, Enterprise and Governance (CCEG) Think Tank (www.cceg.org.uk). 
The aim of the magazine is to generate, stimulate, and disseminate information on Social Value and other Intangibles. Including what leading institutions are presently doing to appreciate social value creation, how institutions and organisations can or should utilize and embed these concepts and associated practices (e.g., social value measurement) to improve performance, how individuals can benefit from these developments to enhance their lives, what developments mean for citizens, and what the potentials for the future are. We have already established a strong network of leading academics, politicians, top company leaders, and social value advocates. The magazine is distributed for free online and in print.

The Victorian Minister for Planning established a Taskforce to investigate the extent of non-compliant, combustible cladding on Victorian buildings following the tragic fire at Grenfell in June, 2017. He appointed Former Premier Ted Baillieu and Former Deputy Premier John Thwaites as Co-Chairs of the Taskforce. I established the Office of the Victorian Cladding Taskforce to support the Co-Chairs in their inquiry and to provide a secretariat to the Taskforce. My role involved engaging senior stakeholders in Government, emergency services and the building and construction sector to review and make recommendations to Victoria's building and fire safety regulation, the delivery of a methodology and pilot audit of high risk buildings, coordination of an audit of state government buildings and recommended a significant increase in the compliance and enforcement activity of the Victorian Building Authority.  The Interim Report of the Taskforce was published on 1 December, 2017.

As director of my own consulting practice, my key piece of work was undertaking an independent review of the regulatory work undertaken by the Environment Protection Authority Victoria. The report, containing 117 recommendations, was accepted in full by EPA and underpins the organisational strategy and transformation. The review and report involved extensive consultation with business, environment groups and the Victorian community. The Compliance and Enforcement Review and compliance and enforcement policy developed through the review underpins the compliance and enforcement approaches of a number of regulators in Australia.

WorkSafe Victoria is Victoria's regulator of occupational health and safety. WorkSafe is
      Victoria's largest business regulator with a strong track record of injury prevention
      
      through support programs and effective compliance and enforcement strategies.

As Director, Legal Services and Investigations at WorkSafe, I headed up the Division responsible for WorkSafe's enforcement and prosecutions.  As one of Victoria's most prominent regulatory experts, I played a key policy and strategic advice role in the development of a national OHS compliance and enforcement policy and the harmonisation of OHS laws nationally. The Division was also the key provider of legal advice on operational issues. I led implementation of key policy and operational reforms as part of WorkSafe's transformation arising from the review of OHS by Chris Maxwell QC. In this role and for 5 years prior as a prosecutor with WorkSafe I was responsible for some of Australia's most high profile OHS prosecutions including the investigation and Supreme Court prosecution of Esso Australia Ltd arising from the Longford Gas Plant Explosion, the collapse of the Corio Bridge and prosecution arising from the death of Brodie Panlock - a landmark prosecution of workplace bullying.

general.headline: Founder and Managing  Director, Envirobank Recycling
general.description:
Founder and Managing Director of Envirobank Recycling, Australia’s most innovative recycling company operating in container deposit markets. An accomplished entrepreneur, Narelle’s vision is to change the way Australians – and the world – recycle, utilising technology to reward consumers for the good they do. #recyclingthatpays. 
Founding Envirobank Recycling in 2008 to incentivise recyclers, Narelle introduced the concept of Reverse Vending Technology and automated depots to Australia. This technology now underpins the Container Deposit Schemes being rolled out in states across Australia.

A born entrepreneur, Narelle has owned multiple businesses and built a distinguished career in the waste industry. In 2000, she became the first aboriginal woman to solely own a waste management company. Her company is a registered Supply Nation Company, appointed by her peers she also co-chairs the  Supply Nations Business Advisory, Group whose charter is work closely with other indigenous companies to help them grow and prosper.

In 2001 she was elected by her peers as the first female president of the Sydney chapter of The Entrepreneurs’ Organisation (EO) a dynamic, global network of more than 12,300 entrepreneurs in 54 countries. 

Under Narelle’s visionary leadership, Envirobank won the Peter Szental Award for Sustainability Entrepreneurship in 2012 @ World Environment Day Awards. 

In 2013 she was nominated for the In Style and Audi Women of Style awards honouring 31 influential women, for their valuable contributions to Australian Society. 

In 2015 Narelle was voted as one of Australia’s top 50 influential women entrepreneurs.
Narelle is a board member of The Australian Council of Recyclers (ACOR) the peak recycling industry body of Australia.
The great niece of the late Senator Neville Bonner, Narelle is passionate about indigenous welfare and has achieved many firsts as an aboriginal woman and entrepreneur, and aspires to make a difference.

jobs.description:
Envirobank Recycling - Recycling that Pays 

Envirobank is a provider of systems and technology to improve the efficiency of  recycling depots .
Envirobank also  runs a retail division that  provides  Reverse Vending Technology to offer public place recycling solutions to retail outlets, universities and councils, combined with a customer acquisition program for brands .

Envirobank NT runs the largest cash for container depot network in the NT and is one of the main scheme coordinators in the cash for containers scheme , it works closely with the beverage industry to deliver efficient and costs effective services .

As the founder and Managing Director I am  responsible for the performance of the company which includes but is not limited to: 

Successfully implementing company policy 
Developing strategic plans

Building and maintaining an effective management team 
Assuming full accountability for the board for all company operation

As a director of EcoSTEPS-Sustainability Partner and Blue Mountains World Heritage Institute, he is  working as a leading advisor in the areas of sustainability strategy and reporting, circular economy, climate change and energy.

Julian is past-president of the International Society of Sustainability Professionals (ISSP) with its global Sustainability Certification program.  He is  representative partner with Global Footprint Network and The Natural Step.  

As a Director with EY Climate Change and Sustainability Services (2014-16) he was the interim CEO of the Australian Supply Chain Sustainability School and also responsible for a wide range of strategy, reporting and assurance projects.

These various roles give him outstanding global perspectives and experience in the rapidly evolving sustainability marketplace. His recent focus has been on a range of sustainability ‘thought leadership’ activities including circular economy, integrated reporting, conference speaking, publications, occasional university lecturer etc.

Julian has a science and business background.  Having originally studied zoology at Oxford University, England, he then worked internationally as a Chartered Accountant with PricewaterhouseCoopers.  

Previously, Julian has provided top level strategic advice across multiple sectors including Government, Financial Services, Property & Infrastructure and Utilities. Emanuel Synagogue is the largest single Jewish community in Australia, with near more than 3500 members. A staff of 52 persons provides administration, professional support to a team of five rabbis, education and facilities management.
 
As a non-executive director:
•	Transition to new President
•	Decision to replace campus redevelopment, realignment of project with community funds, reduce delivery risk
•	Strengthened community balance sheet to AUD30 million, no debt, diversified investment portfolio;
•	Lay-leadership role within the broader community.


The role of Honorary Treasurer, Chair of the Investment, Finance Audit & Risk Committee requires:
•	Financial policy renewal, “community credit” management
•	Allocation of investment portfolio against mandated risk
•	Budget processes oversight, board approval 
•	Audit process oversight, member approval
•	Risk ownership, assignment, reporting

Century Asset Management created a closed end, institutional fund, targeted at solar power investing into Italy to take advantage of federal energy scheme. Capital sourced from London and Italian markets, structured and directed in tax effective cross-border finance.
 
Responsible for the investing the SolarJewel fund:
•	A closed end institutional fund with EUR100 million of subordinated capital sourced for London market, returning 15% gross.
•	Mandate to acquire green-field solar power asset located in Italy at financial close, with exposure to construction and start-up risk. 
•	EUR320 million credit facility from Italian institutions

A portfolio of solar power assets, selected and structured to:
•	Achieve 18% pre-tax internal rate of return
•	Transaction minimum value of EUR25 million 
•	Comply with SolarJewel risk requirements, construction wrapped, asset managed, currency and rates hedged
•	Government policy supported with a component of market volatility
•	Utilize local development, engineering/construction, professional services

jobs.description:
Responsible for the development of ARENA's innovation lab - A-Lab. 
A-Lab is ARENA’s grid integration innovation lab. It draws on a network of people with a wide range of expertise and passion to drive systemic change in the electricity sector. A-Lab provides a space for these people to explore and define solutions to the most complex challenges of integrating renewables and grids, combining their respective strengths and building momentum for change.
www.arena.gov.au/a-lab

A founding partner of RAMP Carbon, an enterprise that works with organizations to design and implement projects in the areas of:
•	renewable energy,
•	energy and water efficiency,
•	waste management and
•	biodiversity preservation. 
  
RAMP Carbon was established in early 2010 and has offices in Mexico City and Melbourne and has delivered a diverse range of project development, carbon trading and advisory projects. My role involves organisational strategy, business development, finance, client management, delivery of technical consulting projects and carbon trading functions. 

Key projects include:
- Negotiation of strategic alliance with large Dutch energy company, Eneco (www.eneco.com) to deliver carbon trading services to the Australian market.
- Securing advisory mandates from blue chip European and Australian clients including BNP Paribas, Standard Bank, Total Oil & Gas, Bunge, Australian Agricultural Co. and the Department of Climate Change.
- Delivering complex scientific and commercial advice to partners involved in the National Livestock Methane Program.

I act as the Responsible Manager in relation to RAMP Carbon's AFSL managing all regulatory, risk and compliance aspects of the licensing requirements.

RAMP Carbon invested in, and incubated the Energy Saving Social Club, a start-up energy services platform providing expert advice, information and offers that help members to save energy and money. ESSC does the hard work for households and small businesses to bring them great deals that will help them:

SWITCH to a better deal for electricity and gas 
SAVE by installing energy saving products 
DIY ENERGY with solar PV, and
GET TOGETHER to support their community

I helped to develop the business strategy and then deliver a 6 month pilot of the business. Through the pilot we acquired foundation customers (including energy retailers, solar PV installers and ESCOs) as well as an initial membership of 2,000 households and small businesses. We are now continuing to grow the membership base and explore new products including community energy projects. My ongoing role on the board is to provide oversight and strategic input into finance and funding, marketing and product development.

www.energysavingsocialclub.com.au

Strong knowledge of the Kyoto Protocol’s Clean Development Mechanism, having led the development of the first Programme of Activities to be registered by the United Nations. The program distributed 25 million energy saving light bulbs to low income households in Mexico. After leading the negotiation of a long term carbon offtake, and structuring a mixture of debt and equity involving private sector and government funding, the project was awarded Carbon Finance Deal of the Year in 2010. 

Experienced in commercial negotiations, structuring of carbon transactions, as well as specialist technical knowledge in energy efficiency, regulatory approvals and methodology development.

Obtained regulatory approvals for demand-side abatement project development within the New South Wales Greenhouse Gas Abatement Scheme.

Managed the company’s carbon credit portfolio, actively trading through the NSW GGAS spot market.

Developed first government approved voluntary carbon methodology for energy saving lights.

Led a research team of analysts in the development of an innovative Corporate Social Responsibility ratings service. 

Engaged with ASX200 companies and major Australian NGOs in the development of ratings methodology; conducted ratings for clients across the energy, mining, financial services and government sectors. Specialised in assessments of exposure to environmental risks and human rights issues.

general.headline: CEO ● Renewable Energy Expert ● Solar & Smart Energy Industry Advocate, Thought Leader & Influencer ● Media Commentator
general.description:
WHAT I DO: I tenaciously advocate for solar and smart energy in public policy, educate the public on the benefits of renewable energy, properly position solar companies, and connect people, companies, partners, and investors. 

HOW I DO IT: I am the CEO of the Australian Solar Council, “the national voice for solar”; CEO of Energy Storage Council; a solar, smart energy, and renewable energy industry advocate, influencer, subject matter expert, and lobbyist; and a consultant, business developer, and media commentator. I focus on how customers can save money; saving the planet is a bonus!

In the public policy sphere, I fight for good policies to help solar, energy storage, and other smart energy systems. My work and comments are the subject of an average of 1,300 TV, radio, print, and online articles a year. I develop and run successful industry campaigns against outdated government policy, with a long track record of changing negative policies and building political, industry, and public coalitions of support to win the day.

In the industry sphere, I run the annual Smart Energy Conference & Exhibition, with over 100 expert speakers, 130 exhibitors, and 4500 delegates; publish the Solar & Storage magazine quarterly (readership of 25,000); and run quality control programs that inspect solar panels to provide the ‘quality tick of approval.

In the business development sphere, I run professional training and help you position your brand, become a thought leader, find new partners and investors, and make more sales through incredible networking opportunities and events shared with our 30,000 subscribers. 

WHO I WORK WITH: 
•	Federal and State Public Policy Makers
•	Renewable Energy Industry Regulators & Standards Bodies
•	Renewable Energy Manufacturers and Contractors
•	Not for Profit Industry Bodies
•	Investors
•	Media
•	Training Organizations

WANT TO TALK? Reach out to me directly here on LinkedIn for membership details or other opportunities and visit solar.org.au.

general.headline: Partner at Baker McKenzie
general.description:
I am a senior partner in Baker McKenzie's Banking and Finance group in Sydney with extensive experience in advising borrowers, sponsors and lenders on leveraged acquisition, corporate and project financing transactions as well as high-value, complex, multi-jurisdictional and cross-border financing transactions. 

I am a seasoned practitioner with over 25 years' broad international experience in banking and finance, major projects, M&A and private equity in emerging and developed markets.  In my time at Baker McKenzie, I have been the Head of Banking & Finance Australia and a member of the Asia Pacific Banking & Finance Steering Committee and the Global Project Finance Steering Committee.

I am currently based in Sydney and have spent 6 years in Baker McKenzie's London and Santiago de Chile offices.  I also previously worked for a leading firm in Papua New Guinea.

As a lead partner of the Banking & Finance Group and relationship partner for a number of financial institutions, Sean has a deep understanding of the financial services industry and the challenges it faces in the current environment.

Sean is known for being a collaborative leader, respected and trusted by his peers and team members both in Australia and internationally.  

I have been lauded across a variety of legal directories with recognition such as "excellent leader", "...acute sense of the market", "customer focused", "responsive", "…considerable international project and acquisition finance expertise", "very impressive", and "very good knowledge of the banking industry".  Chambers Global 2017 notes “Sean Rush is lauded by clients for his "amazing practical knowledge and experience" and being able to "get the best results for his clients.” 

Specialties include: 
Corporate finance
Leveraged and acquisition finance
Cross-border M&A and financing
Major projects and project finance
Private equity
Sustainability, climate change and renewable energy
Foreign Investment
Infrastructure

general.headline: Energy and Infrastructure
general.description:
What sets me apart - I "think" like our clients.

I am an energy and infrastructure lawyer engaging in the global marketplace. I have substantial experience developing and delivering projects across many diverse business cultures - wherever our clients do business. I quickly and confidently adapt to new cultures and their style of transacting.

My approach to business is outcome and quality focused.  I seek to understand and execute our clients' commercial and other objectives through exceptional client service and practical and simple solutions.  I am fortunate to do this alongside a brilliant team of focused, innovative and dedicated lawyers.

Away from work, I invest significant time mentoring university students. I actively engage with many of our Firm's pro-bono clients and charities while also supporting a number of local not-for-profit organisations, particularly focusing on disadvantaged youth.

Chambers & Partners (legal ranking agency) note: 

"Clients state that "he keeps his cool in difficult negotiations, knows what the banks need to fund projects, and understands our commercial drivers." 

"Dan Brown offers substantial experience in the infrastructure and energy sectors across several continents, winning praise for his high levels of activity and expertise. 

"One client enthuses - He understands what we want, he knows what he's doing and he makes everything an easy and productive experience." 

"He gains widespread market praise, with clients highlighting his impressive combination of "commercial acumen and legal knowledge."

"Sources describe him as "really good on EPC work" and assert that "his ideas give us a competitive edge."

Recognised by Best Lawyers in 2015 - 2019 for Energy Law and Construction / Infrastructure Law.

general.headline: Global Greens Ambassador, Patron Australian Solar Council, Advisory Board Climate Accountability,
general.description:
Christine Milne has been appointed as the first Global Greens Ambassador following her resignation as Leader of the Australian Greens and Senator for Tasmania. She was elected to represent Tasmania in the federal parliament in 2004 after a distinguished career in the Tasmanian state parliament (1989-98) where she served as Leader of the Tasmanian Greens from 1993-98. It was her private member's bill that delivered gay law reform in 1997. Christine is an environmental activist  having been arrested and jailed on the campaign to save the Franklin River in 1983 and led the successful campaign to save first class agricultural land from an elemental chlorine pulp mill at Wesley Vale in 1987-89.

Christine served on the Global Council of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) from 2000-2008 with four years as one of the four global Vice Presidents. She represented it at the Conference of the Parties to the Climate Change Convention at Montreal, Nairobi and Bali. She has attended UNFCCC COPs regularly, most recently in Lima.

Christine was the first woman to lead a political party in Tasmania and  is a leader in the environment movement in Australia and overseas. She was appointed to the United Nations Environment Programme’s Global 500 Roll of Honour in 1990 and Has received many awards during her distinguished career. She has been awarded the Inaugural Women in Leadership Award for Tasmania in 2015.
In the Australian Federal Parlaiment she was instrumental in developing the Clean Energy Package which was template legislation for addressing global warming and resulted in establishment of the Climate Change Authority, Australian Renewable Energy Agency, the Clean Energy Finance Corporation, the Biodiversity Fund and the Carbon Farming Initiaitve.

Specialties: Christine's areas of expertise are climate change, renewable energy, biodiversity, ecological sustainability, World Heritage,arts, food security, women and gender equality, and gay rights.

general.headline: CEO at Australian Conservation Foundation
general.description:
A leader and Chief Executive Officer with a record of driving transformative environmental and economic outcomes in climate, water and business sustainability.  An expert in strategy and policy development, organisational growth and crafting innovative programs across the business, government and community sectors. A strategic thinker and trusted advisor and negotiator, Kelly is sought after to lead complex multi-stakeholder collaborations across politics, government, business and the community.

Key capabilities include:
Sustainability: driving substantive and high-profile environment and market outcomes through thought leadership on environmental and economic reform.
Leadership: organisational growth and reform, strategic planning and change management across the government, non-profit and business sectors.
Management: an expert in financial, brand and client growth, staff and culture development and building trusted relationships. 
Organised, innovative, future focused with boundless energy and tenacity.

jobs.description:
Australia's national environment group advocating for nature, climate and people with 80 staff, 500000 supporters & volunteers, $13M turnover. 

Key achievements:

Protecting people & planet: 
•	Prevented Tasmania’s forests from being delisted from World Heritage protection.
•	Over 1 million hectares returned to Indigenous Australians for cultural and conservation outcomes. 
•	Lead in Australia’s largest env. campaign to #StopAdani & switch from coal to clean energy.  
•	Exposed Australia’s ‘broken’ nature laws & collaborated to build next generation nature laws.
•	Collaborated with civil society and business groups advocating for climate and energy policy. 
•	With unions, identified 1 million jobs in clean energy and climate action across Australia. 
•	State leadership on renewable energy, nuclear free communities & restoration of the Murray-Darling.

Reformed an old organisation into modern, ‘go to’ organisation:
•	Created new organisational change strategy and structure.
•	Transformed organisational culture. 
•	Reformed governance arrangements to maximise efficiency, diversity and transparency.  
•	Delivered financial stability and doubled major gifts and bequests.  

Built people power: Grew ACFs supporters from 80,000 to 500,000 using values-based engagement and involving people in our campaigns.

Changed the story: built national narratives and doubled media impact on climate and clean energy, and nature law reform through using investigative journalism and social and mainstream.

Responsible for strategy and operations; financial growth and fundraising; marketing and brand recognition; staff and volunteer development; stakeholder relationships; and thought-leadership through public speaking and media roles. 

Key achievements:
Visionary strategy: Positioned Environment Victoria as one of the most influential environment organisations in Australia and a ‘go to’ environment organisation for political, business and community leaders and the media.   

Financial growth:  Positioned Environment Victoria as the fastest growing environment group in Australia and New Zealand for income growth (growing income 4 fold in 4 years and establishing a $2.15 million endowment fund).  

Client (supporter) growth: Grew Environment Victoria’s supporter-base 13-fold in 4 years 

My staff are recognised as among the most influential people in Melbourne and won a Eureka Award for communicating climate change in 2011.

Climate & energy: Created a highly influential safe climate advocacy program contributing to national emissions reduction and renewable energy schemes; energy efficiency targets and home retrofits, a rooftop solar financial incentive scheme; and a shift in community support away from coal to clean energy.

Rivers and nature: Part of the team negotiating river restoration and reform packages including the internationally recognised reform of the Murray-Darling river system. 

Urban and rural water supplies: Convinced Australian governments to invest $1 billion to improve industry, agriculture and domestic water productivity.  

Waste and recycling: Boosted resource productivity and waste recycling in Australia product stewardship schemes and reforming landfill levies to make recycling more competitive.

Business collaboration: Leading the green economy debate in Victoria through developing a Green Economy Plan, showcasing over 26,000 new jobs in five industry sectors; and forming a roundtable of business leaders

Appointed by the Minister for Water to chair a committee of environment and
      community organisations to provide advice to the government on 21st century water
      
      planning

Responsible for leading the development a 50 year strategic plan to transform and decarbonise Melbourne’s water supply and demand, on behalf of 4 water utility boards and the Victorian government. 

Major achievements:
Secured Melbourne’s future water needs against the challenges of climate change and a rapidly growing population, through a forward thinking, multi-partisan 50 year action plan. 

Decarbonised water infrastructure: for the first time, water planning incorporated climate change into supply forecasts and a transition pathway to zero net emissions. 

Renewed focus on smart water use: secured a three-fold increase in water conservation, saving money, delaying new supply augmentation and creating new opportunities for water markets.

Agreement and political alignment: the plan was supported by all water utility, government and political stakeholders despite divided views in the height of Australia’s longest drought.

Department of Sustainability and Environment
Responsible for the development of Victoria’s Environmental Sustainability Framework and sustainability partnerships with business, on behalf of the Victorian Environment and Water Minister and Treasurer. 

Major achievements:
Secured a pathway to protect natural assets by developing the Victorian Sustainability Framework that set decision-making principles and targets for sustainable development and natural asset restoration. 

Secured government investment of $200 million in over 100 partnerships with communities, businesses and government agencies. 

Achieved bi-partisan political support, as well as support from the business and community sectors.

Established the Victorian Business Sustainability Roundtable with leading company CEO’s to set strategic directions for business sustainability Victorian market sectors.

Manager – Water and Catchment Strategies
Victorian Environment Protection Authority
Led EPA’s water policies and regulations for the water, catchment, shipping and primary production sectors. 

Major achievements:
Set environment protection standards through developing the state environment protection policy (Waters of Victoria), the pre-eminent policy that protects rivers, catchments and marine environments, and sets the standards that underpin environmental regulation. 

Created a world leading waste management policy for industrial waste: Victoria was the first jurisdiction in the world to develop a domestic ships ballast water regulation to prevent marine pests from entering state waters. This necessary but contentious policy followed a cooperative trial with the shipping industry. 

Reformed EPA’s water focus: Expanded EPA’s focus from point source pollution to broader pollution and catchment management

jobs.description:
Clean Growth Choices (CGC) has been designed as a community development process to navigate successfully the transition to a low carbon economy.
CGC is a robust, futures focused, road-mapping framework grounded in place, community and region.

With backgrounds and disciplines relevant to building community resilience and sustainable futures, the CGC team is drawn from two major regional universities, the national science agency and a specialist Brisbane based eco-efficiency consultancy:

USQ's Institute for Resilient Regions
JCU's Cairns Institute at James Cook University
CSIRO’s Climate Risks and Resilience Unit and
The Ecoefficiency Group.

The Rural Economies Centre of Excellence (RECoE) is a joint research initiative between the Queensland Government’s Department of Agriculture and Fisheries, the University of Southern Queensland, The University of Queensland, Central Queensland University and James Cook University.  

The Centre has been established to assist rural economic development and diversification centred on the agricultural food and fibre value chain and related regional industries. The emphasis is on entrepreneurship, technological development, and new models of business and marketing. Our collaboration involves expert economic analysis and econometrics, business expertise and networks, and close engagement and partnership with a wide range of regional and rural economic stakeholders.

The Queensland Trust for Nature is a not-for-profit organisation established for the protection of the natural environment in Queensland.

Landscape fragmentation is recognised as a key threatening process resulting in the loss of biodiversity. Protecting existing remnants and restoring wildlife corridors is critical to the long-term survival of many species. For this reason, the Trust works to protect habitat and compliment public and private protected areas for the conservation of biodiversity.

The Trust operates a revolving fund that is used to buy, covenant and re-sell land with high conservation values. The Trust also develops partnerships with other organisations to identify, acquire, manage and protect land.

To-date the Trust has acquired ten properties and sold five. In excess of 101,000 hectares has been managed for conservation.

The Queensland Plan Ambassadors Council will make sure the community-led vision remains the people’s plan—working with government to oversee the plan’s implementation across Queensland and encourage community participation.

Responsibilities

The Ambassadors represent a range of sectors and regions and are focussed on delivery, accountability and innovation.

Their three roles are:

Advocacy—linking government, business, industry and community sectors.
Independent advice—relating to delivery of community vision and contributing expertise.
Leadership, collaboration and review—including community engagement.

general.headline: Chief Executive at CSIRO
general.description:
I'm Chief Executive of CSIRO, Australia’s National Science Agency and innovation catalyst. CSIRO solves Australia’s greatest challenges, turning excellent science into profound impact in partnership with industry, government, universities and the community.

I'm a scientist, technology innovator and business leader with a wealth of experience in creating new value and impact with science. I have a PhD in Physics and became a global leader in laser research, for which I was honoured as a Federation Fellow and later as an ATSE (Australian Academy of Technology and Engineering) Fellow. 

I invented the “eye-safe” laser which enabled lasers to be used safely in public. I was inspired at Stanford to found my first company, Light Solutions, which invented the world’s first solid-state green laser for the treatment of blindness in diabetics. Light Solutions merged with infra-red laser company Iris Medical in 1995, and the green-laser sales propelled the new company Iridex to IPO (initial public offering) on Nasdaq. 

I was CEO/MD and founder of another five companies, frequently based on Stanford’s science, in biotechnology, telecommunications, semiconductors, and venture capital, including Arasor which I took public in 2006. In 2007, I became MD of Southern Cross Ventures, specialising in Australian innovation, where I delivered the first Nasdaq IPO of an Australian-venture backed startup commercialising science. 

I have over 100 publications and conference papers, hold 20 patents, and have served on 20 boards of high tech companies operating in the US, Australia and China. I am a Male Champion of Change committed to tackling gender equality. I am a passionate supporter of Australian innovation, returning to Australia to lead CSIRO, which I believe is the essential catalyst to improve Australia’s innovation performance.

jobs.description:
Chief Executive, scientist, technology innovator, business leader, Male Champion of
      Change.
      

    
      

    Larry spent the last decade trying to help crack Australia's innovation dilemma, now
      he's working on it from the inside. CSIRO is the best placed organisation in the
      
      innovation ecosystem to influence change and lead by example.

general.headline: Chief Executive Officer at Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR)
general.company: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR)
general.description:
Professor Andrew Campbell (@ACIARCEO) commenced as Chief Executive of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) on 1 August 2016.  ACIAR is a statutory agency in the Foreign Affairs portfolio that invests in research in partner developing countries to improve agricultural productivity and sustainability, and food system security and resilience.

Andrew Campbell moved back to Canberra after 5 years in Darwin, where he led the Research Institute for Environment and Livelihoods and the Centre for Renewable Energy at Charles Darwin University.  He was previously Managing Director of Triple Helix Consulting Pty Ltd, a consultancy working at the interface between science and policy around climate, water, energy and food systems.  Andrew was the Executive Director of Land & Water Australia for seven years to 2006, prior to which he was a senior executive in the Australian Government.  He was instrumental in the development of Landcare in Australia and has written widely on sustainability.  He has professional training in forest science and knowledge systems from the University of Melbourne and Wageningen Agricultural University in The Netherlands. 
 
Andrew is a Fellow of the Australian Institute for Company Directors and Board Member of the Peter Cullen Trust.  His family has been farming in western Victoria since the 1860s.  Andrew has been managing the family farm (farm forestry, prime lambs and wool) with the help of a neighbour since 1987.

Skills: 
•	Leadership in team and network-oriented contexts at the intersection between research and policy
•	Research strategy and management
•	Strategic analysis and strategic planning
•	Knowledge management within and across organisations
•	Natural resource management, including climate, carbon, water, energy, food and biodiversity
•	Corporate, program and project management and program evaluation
•	Corporate governance – public, non-profit and private sectors

jobs.companyName: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR)
jobs.description:
The Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) invests in applied research to improve agricultural productivity and sustainability, and food system resilience in developing countries.  The Centre is Australia’s specialist international agricultural research for development (R4D) agency.  It is an Australian Government statutory authority within the Foreign Affairs portfolio. 

ACIAR works with over thirty countries in the Indo-Pacific region through bilateral and multilateral research partnerships.  We invest around $100m per annum with a wide range of research providers in Australia and partner countries.  The beneficiaries of these programs include farmers, rural poor, consumers, researchers and policymakers.  Australian farmers, agribusinesses and researchers also benefit tangibly through, for example, knowledge and technology exchange, preventing or solving problems before they reach Australia, and building linkages that can foster future trade relationships.

ACIAR was established by the Fraser Government in 1982 via the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Act (ACIAR Act), described at the time as ‘An Act to encourage research for the purpose of identifying, or finding solutions, to, agricultural problems of developing countries’.

The Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) is an overarching and integrated network designed to serve ecosystem research in Australia. It builds on significant past investments by scientists and governments to understand Australian ecosystems. It does this by focussing on collating, calibrating, validating and standardising existing data sets. TERN is also funding new research infrastructure and collection systems, expanding observation and monitoring programs into unrepresented ecosystems, and building digital infrastructure to store and publish this information in a form that can be searched and accessed freely under licenses that acknowledge the data provider(s) and build collaborative research.

jobs.description: The Research Institute for the Environment and Livelihoods undertakes integrated biophysical, social and economic research with a focus on tropical and desert environments in Northern Australia and in similar climatic regions globally, with emphasis on Southeast Asia. The Institute aims to balance conservation and development,  improving human well-being through responsible natural resource management.
