Future Farm Industries Cooperative Research Centre Ltd  is an incorporated joint venture playing a crucial role in developing new and innovative farming systems and technologies to improve the resilience of Australian broadacre agriculture to climate change, salinity, climate variability and drought while improving productivity and sustainability. Future Farm Industries CRC was established in 2007 through the Australian Government’s Cooperative Research Centre Program.

Andrew Campbell is the Managing Director of Triple Helix Consulting Pty Ltd, a consultancy firm specialising in the business of sustainability, helping progressive organisations in the public and private sectors to develop and implement more sustainable policies, programs and enterprises.  Recent clients include the Australian Government, catchment management organisations, large scale sustainable farming enterprises, international research bodies and Australian R&D corporations.

Land & Water Australia was a statutory corporation from 1990-2009 within the Commonwealth Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry portfolio, established under the Primary Industries and Energy R&D Act and the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act.  Its primary purpose was to organise and fund research and development activities aimed at the productive and sustainable management of Australia’s natural resources.  The Executive Director is the Chief Executive, a member of the Board and responsible to it for all aspects of the Corporation including:  strategic direction and policy;  leadership of a staff of ~40;  research and development programs;  partnerships for funding and managing R&D (~$35m per annum across 45 partners and 16 programs);  communication and adoption of R&D outputs;  management of knowledge assets;  sound and effective financial management;  and meeting all accountability requirements.  Andrew Campbell’s seven year tenure saw considerable growth and development of the corporation, characterised by constructive collaborative engagement with stakeholders, closer connections with both policy and industry audiences, a focus on managing knowledge for adoption, developing new initiatives in building research capacity, doubling turnover while maintaining excellence across the research portfolio.  The corporation published two books synthesising some of the lessons from this experience;  The Australian Natural Resource Management Knowledge System (2006) and The Getting of Knowledge – a guide to funding and managing applied research (2007)

Environment Australia at the time was the Australian Ministry of the Environment.  The role of Assistant Secretary (SES1), Sustainable Landscapes Branch carried responsibility for the development and implementation of the $360 million Bushcare Program – the largest of the environment programs funded through the $1.5 billion Natural Heritage Trust (NHT).  The role of managing Bushcare combined intense pressures to develop national policy, with the demands of designing, administering and accounting for a large operational program, managing a staff of over fifty professionals and overseeing a national network of more than 200 people.  The position also entailed responsibility for a $40m NHT investment to secure the natural and cultural values of Cape York Peninsula;  the $30m private land component of the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement;  and the Bush for Greenhouse initiative to facilitate corporate investment in vegetation sinks.

The National Landcare Facilitator (NLF) project was a consultancy to the Australian Soil Conservation Advisory Committee which advised the Minister for Primary Industries.  The consultancy arose out of voluntary work in mid-1988 to help the nascent alliance between the National Farmers’ Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation to draft a proposal for the Australian government.  This proposal secured bipartisan support for a Decade of Landcare built on assistance for group approaches and integrated planning at property and catchment scales.  The NLF role involved meeting landcare groups and the people working with them throughout Australia, analysing their effectiveness, facilitating communication across state, disciplinary and institutional boundaries, and providing strategic advice to policy makers at State and national levels.  It provided a unique opportunity to explore the full range of land management issues and participatory approaches to research and extension, and to develop a contact network of outstanding farmers, scientists and extension agents throughout Australia.  This experience was the basis for the book “Landcare—communities shaping the land and the future”, published in 1994 by Allen and Unwin, Sydney.

The Potter Farmland Plan, funded by the Ian Potter Foundation, established fifteen model farms in Western Victoria to demonstrate how farm layout and management can be planned to incorporate ecological principles at a landscape scale.  The position of Project Manager entailed responsibility for leading the implementation of the program;  working with people (2 professionals, 15 families and 22 community groups);  planning and delivery of extension activity;  preparation of budgets and accountability for expenditure (~$1m);  liaison with Government and other institutions with regard to monitoring, research and extension;  development and extension of the concept of Whole Farm Planning;  development, application and extension of efficient and effective techniques of revegetation on rural land; and development and delivery of a comprehensive public relations program and documentation of the project.  This experience led to the writing of “Planning for Sustainable Farming”, published by Lothian Books, Melbourne 1991.

jobs.companyName: Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands
jobs.description: Postings to Stawell, Bendigo and Shepparton, with an emphasis on farm tree extension(including administration of the Tree Growing Assistance Scheme and the Farm Forestry Loan Scheme);  forest recreation planning;  fire protection planning, fire training and supervision of fire prevention works (including extensive involvement (mainly as a Sector Boss) in the fires leading up to and including ‘Ash Wednesday’);  supervision of the road construction program in the Grampians National Park;  and development of management plans for the Rushworth State Forest.

general.description:
Rob retired from executive leadership in the Australian Public Service in April 2016 and is now involved in research and consulting . He is an Enterprise Professor in the School of Engineering at the University of Melbourne and an Honorary Professor in the Climate Change Institute at the Australian National University. He is undertaking research on water security and climate change. Rob is also the principal of his consulting firm Global Change Advisory, providing strategic advice and capacity development in the use of environmental intelligence for managing water scarcity under changing climate conditions. 

Specialties: Catchment hydrology, forest hydrology, hydrologic modelling, research management, organisational leadership, hydro-climatic variability, climate change, water security, water information, environmental intelligence.

OUR VISION

To unlock the mysteries of the Universe using innovative 3D technology, while sharing the excitement and wonder of astronomy to inspire the broader community.

OUR MISSION

To propel Australia to the forefront of astronomical research by combining Australia’s radio, optical and theoretical expertise to understand the origins of our Universe and the galaxies within it.

To share our discoveries and passion for research with the broadest possible audience and inspire the scientists of the future.

Undertaking research on climate change and water security. I'm interested in
      assessment methods, monitoring systems and forecasting approaches that can be
      
      used to harden water security under hydroclimatic changes.

Global Change Advisory provides strategic advice and capacity development in the use of environmental intelligence for managing water scarcity under changing climate conditions. The Principal, Professor Rob Vertessy, draws on his prior experience as a research leader in CSIRO, government agency head at the Bureau of Meteorology and contributor to Australian water reform policy at the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. Rob was the architect of the Australia's national water information reforms that resulted in the creation of the high value water information services at www.bom.gov.au/water.

My research interests are in the areas of climate variability and climate change and
      
      their impacts on water security.

During this period I headed up the Australian Bureau of Meteorology. For the first year I was acting in the role and was made substantive agency head in September 2012.

The Bureau of Meteorology is Australia's national weather, climate and water agency. Its expertise and services assist Australians in dealing with the harsh realities of their natural environment, including drought, floods, fires, storms, tsunami and tropical cyclones. Through regular forecasts, warnings, monitoring and advice spanning the Australian region and Antarctic territory, the Bureau provides one of the most fundamental and widely used services of government.

The Bureau contributes to national social, economic, cultural and environmental goals by providing observational, meteorological, hydrological and oceanographic services and by undertaking research into science and environment related issues in support of its operations and services.

The Bureau of Meteorology operates under the authority of the Meteorology Act 1955 and the Water Act 2007 which provide the legal basis for its activities, while its operation is continually assessed in accordance with the national need for climatic records, water information, scientific understanding of Australian weather and climate and effective service provision to the Australian community. The Bureau of Meteorology must also fulfill Australia's international obligations under the Convention of the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and related international meteorological treaties and agreements.

During this time I was Australia's Permanent Representative to the WMO, a member of the WMO Executive Council and co-chair of the WMO Executive Council's Expert Panel on Polar Observations, Research and Systems.

Specialties: Catchment hydrology, forest hydrology, hydrologic modelling, research management, organisational leadership.

Independent Litigation Funders is a commercial entity that contracts with one or more potential litigants. Independent Litigation Funders pays the cost of any proposed or subsisting litigation and, in doing so, accepts the risk of paying the other party’s costs if the case fails in addition to the costs of the litigant.   On the other hand, if the case is successful, Independent Litigation Funders is paid a share of the proceeds. The share of the proceeds is as agreed with the client.

The International Commission of Jurists (ICJ) is an international human rights non-governmental organisation.
The Commission itself is a standing group of 60 eminent jurists (including senior judges, attorneys and academics) dedicated to ensuring respect for international human rights standards through the law. Commissioners are known for their experience, knowledge and fundamental commitment to human rights. The composition of the Commission aims to reflect the geographical diversity of the world and its many legal systems.
The Commission is supported by an International Secretariat based in Geneva, Switzerland, and staffed by lawyers drawn from a wide range of jurisdictions and legal traditions. The Secretariat and the Commission undertake advocacy and policy work aimed at strengthening the role of lawyers and judges in protecting and promoting human rights and the rule of law.
In addition, the ICJ has national sections and affiliates in over 70 countries. Given the legal focus of the ICJ's work, membership of these sections is predominantly drawn from the legal profession.

Australian Lawyers for Human Rights (ALHR) is a leading and well-respected Australian human rights legal organisation established over 20 years ago in 1993.
ALHR has a national membership of over 3,000 Australian lawyers, barristers, judicial officers, legal academics and law students, with active National, State and Territory committees.
ALHR seeks to utilise its’ extensive experience and expertise in the principles and practice of international law and human rights law in Australia in order to:
•	Promote and support lawyers practice of human rights law in Australia
•	Promote Federal and State laws across Australia that comply with the principles of international human rights law.
•	Assist victims of human rights violations in Australia.
Through the provision of training, education, publications, CLE courses, conferences, seminars, mentoring and internships, ALHR assists members to continue to develop their knowledge of human rights law and incorporate human rights principles into their areas of legal practice in Australia.

Standards Australia is the nation's peak non-government Standards organisation. It is charged by the Commonwealth Government to meet Australia's need for contemporary, internationally aligned Standards and related services.

The work of Standards Australia enhances the nation's economic efficiency, international competitiveness and contributes to community demand for a safe and sustainable environment.
It leads and promotes a respected and unbiased Standards development process ensuring all competing interests are heard, their points of view considered and consensus reached.

Standards Australia's key priorities:

•	Standards Development
A range of development pathways is offered to stakeholders looking to develop new or update existing Standards. 

•	National and International Standards Information and Coordination
Standards Australia is the central point for government, industry and the community to find information about non-government consensus Standards in Australia and around the world, and how to participate in their development.

•	Accreditation of Standards Development Organisations
Standards Australia supports the accreditation of other Standards Development Organisations through the Accreditation Board for Standards Development Organisations (ABSDO). This highly autonomous body independently assesses and approves other organisations such as industry associations to develop Australian Standards.

The North Sydney Chamber of Commerce provides local community events and services for people and businesses within the North Sydney Council local government area. Membership includes businesses, educational facilities and NFP organisations. The breadth of the membership provides a vibrant pool for business connections.

NSCC is a not-for-profit membership organisation that receives no external funding for its day-to-day operations and, as such, is able to provide fully independent advice and assistance on a large range of business activities and information. When required the NSCC can refer businesses to other private and government agencies for assistance including recruitment and training, business planning, financial, legal and taxation, sales and marketing, strategic planning needs, statistics, and occupational health and safety information.

general.headline: Professor of Global Change, Environment, and Society at Deakin University
general.description: Professor Bryan is an internationally-recognised research leader focused on creating cost-effective policy and management solutions for people and the environment. As a geographer, he has research interests in the application and development of computational tools and analytical methods in a diverse array of social and environmental contexts. He has expertise and over 20 years of experience in quantitative spatio-temporal data analysis and modelling. He has domain expertise in integrated modelling and assessment of land use and ecosystem services, and has worked in both terrestrial and marine environments. Dr Bryan’s research interests are at the human/environment interface combining aspects of land use and management; agriculture and food security; water resources management; global change impact assessment, mitigation, and adaptation; biodiversity conservation; energy analysis; and economic and policy analysis. He has conducted research in China, India, Indonesia, the United States, and many parts of Australia. He has successfully delivered several major research projects including the Lower Murray Landscape Futures and the land use component of the Australian National Outlook where he led the development and application of the Land Use trade-Offs (LUTO) model, assessing future scenarios for land use economic and environmental sustainability. Most recently, he led a team of 19 scientists from 16 institutions in a major review of China's recent investment in sustainability. His current research interests lie in assessing the options for feeding humanity within the Earth's safe operating space.

general.headline: Senior Managing Director at Macquarie Group
general.description:
Steve is the Head of the Asia Pacific Investor Solutions Group for Macquarie Infrastructure and Real Assets (MIRA), the world’s largest infrastructure asset manager. In this role, Steve leads the development of new real assets platforms and institutional relationships of MIRA’s new businesses in Asia and Australia. He is also a member of MIRA’s Global Management Team.

Steve has led the establishment of 14 of MIRA's new infrastructure businesses. These include MIRA’s first Pan-Asia platform, a number of infrastructure businesses in China and the Philippines and has overseen significant growth in the Korean infrastructure and Chinese real estate platforms - increasing AUM by $A10.7bn. 

Steve was previously the Chief Operating Officer (COO) of the Macquarie European Infrastructure Funds with more than A$10bn under management. During his time as COO, the team and equity under management grew rapidly, making a number of landmark investments including that in Thames Water.

Steve has spoken at numerous industry conferences, including: Fund Forum Asia, AIST, ASFA, Asia Institute Investor Summit as well as PEI Infrastructure Investor; and he regularly contributes to various industry publications on the infrastructure and real assets sectors including Infrastructure Investor, Asia Money, Global Capital and Euromoney. 

Prior to starting his career advising the Victorian government on some of the early public private partnerships in Australia while at Price Waterhouse, Steve developed his honours thesis on the positive impact of government infrastructure spending on private sector growth in Australia.

Steve earned his Bachelor of Commerce from the University of Melbourne, with Honours and his Master in Business Administration from the London Business School where he graduated with Distinction.

Steve is also a passionate supporter of a number of non-profit organisations, in particular those which support disadvantaged children in developing countries in Asia.

general.headline:
Executive Director - Energy Policy Institute of Australia 
         & Managing Director -  ResourcesLaw International
general.description:
Robert Pritchard is an Australian based energy expert who is: 

* Executive Director of the Energy Policy Institute of Australia – Australia’s only apolitical, independent energy policy body 
* Managing Director of ResourcesLaw International, a specialist energy industry consultancy established in 1988
* Chairman of the board of SMR Nuclear Technology Pty Ltd 
* Chairman of the board of the St Baker Energy Innovation Fund
* A consultant in the Sydney office of the Australian law firm Piper Alderman
* A lecturer in the Masters Program on Global Energy and Resources Law at the University of Sydney.

Robert previously served for 9 years on the Finance Committee of the World Energy Council. He was the first Chairman of the Energy Law Section of the International Bar Association (IBA) and served for 4 years on the IBA Council.

Robert also served for 4 years on the Advisory Committee of the CSIRO Energy Transformed Flagship Research Project.

Robert has over 40 years’ experience advising on energy and infrastructure projects, spanning all forms of fossil fuels and renewables. He has often acted as a consultant to the APEC Energy Working Group.

He has published widely on energy and climate change law and policy.

jobs.description:
The Energy Policy Institute is Australia's only apolitical, independent energy policy body. It is technology-neutral in its work, supporting renewables, fossil fuels and nuclear power subject in all cases to appropriate environmental safeguards. Safety is a paramount consideration. 

The Institute advocates that the world should move to a low-carbon society as fast as it can afford to do so, utilising all available technologies, and that individual countries should share the burden equitably

Membership of the Institute comprises a cross-section of leading corporations and organisations across the energy, energy-technology, financial and services sectors and includes three university institutes. Robert is the Executive Director, reporting to a four-person Executive Committee and to a board that is broadly representative of the membership.

In March each year, the Institute hosts the Energy State of the Nation, the most important event on Australia's energy policy calendar.

The Institute publishes a series of public policy papers by thought leaders on topical energy issues that are distributed to members of Parliament around Australia.

The St Baker Energy Innovation Fund is an Australian private equity fund that invests in start-ups in the energy innovation sector.

The Founder of the Fund is Trevor St Baker of Brisbane who is well known as the Founder of ERM Power, an Australian energy utility.

Robert is a consultant with the Piper Alderman law firm, where he advises clients on
      
      strategic and policy issues affecting the energy industry.

For over 25 years ResourcesLaw International has successfully provided independent advice to governmental and industrial clients on strategic, policy and regulatory issues affecting foreign and domestic investment in the energy industry.

Robert has a deep understanding of natural gas (including pipelines and LNG projects) and the electricity, aluminium and nuclear industries.

general.headline: Group Head of Sustainability and Community, Westpac
general.description:
I lead sustainability across the Westpac Banking Group. I am passionate about the capacity of business to create positive impact.

My role covers sustainability strategy governance including climate change and human rights policy, community partnerships and Indigenous engagement, as well as the Westpac Foundation - backing organisations and social enterprises tackling social disadvantage, and Westpac Scholars – awarding 100 scholarships every year, forever. 

Westpac has been ranked the global banking leader for four years straight by the respected Dow Jones Sustainability Index (DJSI).  And previously when I was with the property group Stockland, where I established the sustainability program, it too was ranked as the DJSI global sector leader (real estate). In 2018 I was recognised by the Australian Financial Review as one of Australia's 100 Women of Influence.

My design and advocacy skills were honed through working in urban design and architecture with Lendlease, and the Urban Design Advisory Service - a government-based consultancy.

I create value by strengthening business purpose. Often this means helping businesses balance stakeholder views to make difficult decisions - working through short-term issues to create long-term value and to 'do the right thing'.

Collaboration is key to how I work - engaging internal and external stakeholders and enlisting board and executive support so that sustainability practices are embedded into everyday business activities. 

I'm proud of the high-performance enterprise-wide sustainability teams I've developed, helping businesses achieve measurable environmental, social, financial and reputational outcomes.

Specialties:
- Sustainability strategy & reporting
- Climate change 
- Human rights 
- Eco-efficiency & green building
- Urban design & policy
- Diversity including Indigenous engagement
- Community development, wellbeing & liveability indices
- Social impact, philanthropy & volunteering programs
- Responsible sourcing

jobs.jobTitle: Group Head of Sustainability and Community
jobs.description:
I lead sustainability and community at Westpac - a major Australian financial institution that has been ranked as the world's most sustainable bank by the Dow Jones Sustainability Index for the last four years. 

My team is responsible for the Group's sustainability strategy - shaped around addressing pressing social issues including responding to demographic change, economic solutions to environmental challenges and helping customers achieve sustainable financial futures. 

We bring sustainability to life and create opportunities to realise new value - for Westpac's people, customers, and the Australian community. 

I am also responsible for community partnerships and engagement, the Westpac Foundation, the Westpac Bicentennial Foundation and Indigenous engagement.

jobs.jobTitle: General Manager, Corporate Responsibility and Sustainability
jobs.description:
Established the sustainability function at an ASX50 property group, garnering senior leadership commitment, supporting a highly engaged sustainability board committee and leading significant strategic and cultural change - culminating in Stockland recognised as the world's most sustainable property group by the Dow Jones Sustainability Index in 2011. Since 2010 Stockland has been a concurrent member of the DJSI, the Carbon Disclosure Leadership Index and the Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations.

Evaluated emerging issues (from climate change to greenfield development impacts to supply chain ethics) as seen through the eyes of stakeholders - reframing these issues as business opportunities. Built organisational awareness, guided responses and established ownership. Worked across business functions (including risk, strategy, and HR) as well as directly with profit centres - embedding new practices into everyday business activities to create new value.

Developed an organisation-wide high performance sustainability team responsible for implementing environmental, community development, stakeholder engagement, communications, employee giving and volunteering programs.

Established metrics at enterprise level addressing eco-efficiency performance, liveability and other environmental and social impacts linked to financial outcomes. Delivered award-winning third-party assured sustainability reports and participated in the International Integrated Reporting Pilot. Established NGERS and Energy Efficiency Opportunity reporting capability including the development of online management tools. Trusted business advisor, advocate and spokesperson.

Devised and implemented a climate change action plan delivering significant energy efficiency savings (office portfolio > 38% reduction; retail portfolio > 18% reduction) and more than $20 million return on investment. Created the sustainability vision and case for Stockland's internationally awarded 6 Star Green Star head office.

As the group's first national urban design manager, contributed to the formation of the
      Stockland Design House. Established and championed project visions and
      leading-practice design principles in the masterplanning of award-winning residential
      
      communities.

general.headline: Creative Catalyst / Author / Educator / Artist / Partnership Facilitator / Community Builder / Sustainability Advocate
general.description:
A portfolio of arts, creativity and science for social change. 

Maria Simonelli is a creative change catalyst who fluidly blends careers and interests. She is passionate about encouraging others to dive into the power of their potential. Her vision? A society made richer through meaningful partnerships, exploration and quests borne from curiosity. 

While the list grows as her side projects tend to take a life of their own, Maria has spent the past two decades playing at the intersection of sustainability, capacity building and creative problem solving.  A Renaissance woman, she now combines the creativity and sciences to provide vibrant and energising approaches to social change.  

A creative catalyst… as one of those rare people who can effortless hop between the arts and sciences, Maria has an intriguing range of problem-solving tools at her fingertips. From supporting others to seize technological opportunities to drawing on the psychology of the human brain. She has launched a creative consultancy for those seeking catalytic change in their lives, their workplaces and beyond. 

A bridge between worlds, experience in high-level management roles have tuned Maria's skills as a conduit across diverse sectors. From non-profits, business, governments and community, each role finds common ground, to exchange ideas and facilitate partnerships that create vibrant and sustainable communities. 

A sculptress of sustainability... Maria's art works are informed by her desire to cross pollinate fresh ideas. 

A career redesigner... Maria is the creator and author of Sweet Spot Careers, a boutique consultancy for professionals who've reached their mid careers and are baffled by what to do next. Her message is simple: act on your curiosity and explore the next transition without fear to find clarity and a career you love.  

She is also a Churchill Memorial Fellow and recipient of a Commonwealth Leadership Scholarship. 

wwwmsimonelliportfolio.com.au
www.mariasimonelli.com

jobs.description:
The Creative Catalyst supports individuals and organisations to explore their creativity
      and discover new approaches to problem solving, ways of operating and integrate
      these into our lives and workplaces to facilitate positive social and cultural change.
      

    
      www.thecreativecatalyst.com.au

Current Clients
Telco Together Foundation (2014-18) 
The Telco Together Foundation is a non profit, providing a platform for telecommunications industry to make a significant social contribution. I'm supporting this Foundation by providing strategic and project management expertise to facilitate partnerships and enable engagement opportunities across the sectors.

Greenfleet (2015)
A non profit environmental organisation, focused on climate protection through restorative planting and biodiverse carbon offsets. I supported this organisation by facilitating a campaign development process to engage individuals, businesses, NGOs, councils and universities.

Toombak Indigenous Production (2014)
Toombak, a majority owned indigenous media company, produce television, radio and digital media content from an indigenous perspective for the Australian audience. I assisted by undertaking a strategic facilitation process to support the next phase of their growth phase.

Director and Artist of Project Reclaim. This is an organic sculpture series made from
      antique or remnant fabrics and organic materials to create unique sculptural pieces.
      
      Pieces are sold and donated to charity. Go to www.projectreclaim.com.au

I’m influenced by urban trends and contemporary issues and interested in questioning everyday patterns by intervening and provoking alternative forms of discourse. I hope that my artworks assist to transition a viewer to make connections between disparate ideas and give a different perspective on something they are already aware of. Above all I value the awake, curious and creative mind that cross pollinates ideas to join the dots and build new ideas. 

YouTube Channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbnNWyaD973T8mZZtA5CGbQ

general.headline: I help companies stand out and stand for something. Social Purpose & PR expert💥💥
general.description:
I help companies find their social purpose and tell their story in a meaningful way so they STAND OUT and STAND FOR SOMETHING. Because today 91% of consumers would switch brands to one that supports a good cause. 

Standing for something is vital in today’s purpose revolution, as staff and customers want to know how companies are making the world a better place. If they stand for something they are rewarded with trust and loyalty and if they’re not they are boycotted.

I have developed the Stand For Something Program, that takes a company through four steps to uncover what one key issue they should support and own, these are:

ASSESS: first we assess to see if you support the right cause in the right way. We look at your values to see if you are bringing them to life and see what key issues your staff and customers care about and what the gaps are.  

ALIGN: after careful assessment and input from your staff, customers and management we align you with the ideal cause that supports your values and business goals. 

AMPLIFY: we then infuse your social purpose into the DNA of your company. We ensure internal staff are engaged with your cause so support isn’t just an add-on PR exercise. Then create meaningful storytelling & values-driven PR. 

ANALYSE: we then measure the impact of your social purpose (the measurable good you have done to your chosen cause), we also measure your social media engagement and PR exposure based on your values. 

To kick start all this we run workshops that help companies find, support and promote their one key cause in a meaningful and long-term way so any charity support is never just a PR exercise but done authentically. 

Please get in touch for a free assessment of your company’s current social purpose and ideas to help you get on the path to purpose.

jobs.description:

general.headline: Founder of City Hub
general.description:
AltMedia is one of the few independent newspaper companies to publish local news and information in Sydney.  Australia is one of the most consolidated media markets in the western world: two newspaper companies control the lion share of all local, regional, rural and daily newspapers. Rupert Murdoch's News Corp and Fairfax Media control virtually all newsprint communication in Australia. And a handful of other mogul run companies control all magazine and broacast media outlets. AltMedia competes in that marketplace. We are always looking for individuals who wish to participate, contribtute to or advertise in our fiercely independent newspaper: the City Hub

Specialties: Publishing independent newspapers

jobs.description:
The City Hub is Sydney’s last remaining independent community newspaper -- providing vital coverage for the inner city. In 1995 the first issue of the City Hub hit the streets vowing to “print the news and raise hell”. Over the last two decades the Hub has promoted more than a half million performances, events and shows. We have broken news and offered alternative views to Sydney’s mainstream media outlets. We are not your everyday paper. 

Australia is the most consolidated media market in the free world. One publisher, Rupert Murdoch controls 57% of all daily newspaper distribution in the country. No other western democracy has allowed so many media assets to be controlled by one corporation. For 20 years the City Hub has provided an independent alternative to the mainstream media.

jobs.jobTitle: Group Publisher Alternative Media Group of Australia
jobs.description: Group Publisher

The Alternative Media Group of Australia publishes four indpendent publications serving inner Sydney: the City Hub, which was founded in 1995 and is distributed from Bondi to Balmain targeting young readers between the ages of 18 and 44; the Sydney City News, which is home delivered in the City of Sydney providing community news coverage to City residents and the Bondi and Eastern Suburbs View, which is home distributed in the eastern beaches, providing community news coverage in Sydney's affluent eastern suburbs; and the Inner West Independent serving Leichhardt Council.

general.headline: Partner, Global Head of Pro Bono and Corporate Responsibility at Ashurst

I am a Partner and Ashurst's Global Head of Pro Bono and Corporate Responsibility (CR). I work full-time in pro bono and CR and set the strategic direction of the firm's global pro bono practice and global CR programme.  I have a background in human rights law, gender rights and reproductive rights.

I helped to create the UK Collaborative Plan for Pro Bono.  This initiative involves a UK aspirational pro bono hours target as well as enables law firms to work together to further develop pro bono in the UK and improve access to justice for the most disadvantaged.

Recognitions: 
- Named as one of the Australian Financial Review and Westpac's 100 Women of Influence 2016.
- Winner of the Lawyers Weekly Women in Law Awards 2016 Pro Bono Lawyer of the Year Award.
- Winner of the Australian Woman of the Year in the UK 2014 Award.
- I have been presented at Buckingham Palace to the Queen and Prince Philip at a reception for prominent Australians living in the UK.
- I received an award for being one of the 2011 WorldSpreads’ 30 Under 30. These awards “celebrated the 30 most successful and influential young individuals in the City of London”.

Memberships:
- Qualified Lawyer in Australia (NSW) and England & Wales

- Member of PILnet's (Public Interest Law Network) Leadership Committee
- Member of TrustLaw's Pro Bono Council
- Chair (and previously Vice Chair) of the International Bar Association Pro Bono Committee
- Member of the Business Council of Australia's Indigenous Engagement Taskforce

jobs.jobTitle: Partner, Global Head of Pro Bono and Corporate Responsibility
jobs.description:
I am a Partner and Ashurst's Global Head of Pro Bono and Corporate Responsibility (CR). I work full-time in pro bono and CR and set the strategic direction of the firm's global pro bono practice and global CR programme. Pro bono at Ashurst operates as a stand-alone legal practice, where pro bono clients experience the same levels of service as commercial clients. The practice operates to assist disadvantaged and marginalised people of limited means; non-profit organisations and social enterprises assisting people who are disadvantaged and marginalised; and in matters for the public good of broad public or community concern. CR at Ashurst focuses on volunteering and giving, reconciliation, business community leadership and the environment

I also work with the in-house legal teams of Ashurst's corporate clients to develop pro bono and CR opportunities for in-house lawyers and understand the practical, legal, regulatory and insurance issues facing in-house lawyers in the delivery of pro bono services.

I ran Reed Smith’s pro bono practice in London and across Europe, the Middle East and Asia (EMEA). This stand-alone practice focused on improving access to justice, using the firm’s specialist skills to assist communities and using the firm’s multi-jurisdictional capabilities on high-impact, rights-based projects. I also developed a highly successful programme of partnering with corporate clients on pro bono matters, pro bono clinics and pro bono legal education. 

I was responsible for running Reed Smith’s CR agenda, which included community investment programmes, as well as overseeing the charitable fundraising, environment, supply chain, diversity & inclusion and risk & ethics management initiatives across EMEA. 

I developed and implemented a pro bono and CR strategy which focused on engagement, impact and relationships. 

I was responsible for all pro bono & CR reporting and performance monitoring/evaluation, and the development and management of the pro bono & CR budget.

I had a highly visible role both internally and externally. I was a spokesperson for Reed Smith internationally. I was responsible for all pro bono & CR communications in EMEA, including the pro bono & CR Report, weekly internal blogs, internal newsletter, intranet, website and social media.

general.headline: Pro Bono Partner--
general.description:
Anne is a partner in Gilbert + Tobin’s Pro Bono group. 

Our pro bono practice has a particular focus on legal issues affecting Indigenous Australians, people with disabilities and refugees.

Anne has extensive experience in assisting people who are disadvantaged and marginalised and the organisations working with them across a range of areas of law.

Anne has acted in public interest and test case litigation in relation to judicial independence, discrimination, the capacity of people with cognitive impairment or mental illness to participate in proceedings affecting them, consumer law and imprisonment without conviction.

Anne has been an active contributor to the development of pro bono practice in Australia, from the establishment of pro bono practice within commercial firms, to expanding the skills of commercial lawyers to enable them to meet the needs of pro bono clients, to work aimed at addressing the causes of disadvantage.

Anne has a particular interest in the law as it affects people with cognitive impairment and/or mental illness and has presented and consulted widely on this.

Anne is on the management committee of Kingsford Legal Centre at the University of NSW, the Indigenous Issues Committee of the Law Society of NSW, and is a founding member of Justice Reinvestment Inc.

Anne has a Master of Criminology (First Class Honours), Bachelor of Laws and Bachelor of Arts from the University of Sydney.

jobs.description:

Coordinates law and policy reform work, particularly in relation to the over-representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in custody and the failure of the law to recognise fetal alcohol spectrum disorder.
Develops the pro bono practice nationally.
Develops new areas of practice that meet community need.
Builds relationships internally and externally to enable us to effectively serve our pro bono clients.

Responsible for developing and overseeing the pro bono practice across all 27 Ashurst offices in 16 countries, developing guidelines and procedures for pro bono in the merged firm and developing and implementing a strategy for pro bono in line with the Firm’s strategy.
Managing and (where appropriate) supervising work on major matters including large-scale litigation, work across offices and/or across practice areas and law reform work.  
Contributing to the development of pro bono in commercial law firms in the jurisdictions in which Ashurst operated.

Practice head of the pro bono practice of over 1,200 matters, over 40,000 hours legal work, with a participation rate of 92% of all fee earners across 11 offices in Australasia.
Supervising partner on nearly 250 matters including law reform, larger litigation matters, not-for-profit governance, work outside the Firm’s usual expertise and projects including the Not-for- Profit Health Check Clinics, the Direct Payment Agreement Advice Program and our work building capacity in Indigenous organisations.
Responsible for developing and implementing the pro bono strategic plan, hiring, training and supporting the pro bono team, developing the budget and managing to budget, ensuring the pro bono practice met its targets, monitoring performance against the strategic plan and reporting internally and externally.
Ensuring work was undertaken efficiently to make best use of our resources and to  a high standard including creating training and detailed precedents and checklists.

Building and maintaining relationships in the community legal sector and among organisations, particularly Indigenous organisations and organisations working with people with cognitive disability and/or mental illness and organisations in rural, regional and remote areas.

general.description:
David Chambers started his music career in London playing in clubs by night and holding down various ad hoc jobs including working on spotlights at the London Palladium for Tommy Steele’s long running “Singin’ In The Rain”, and selling ‘swag’ merchandise outside of music venues across the U.K and Europe. Opportunities to work for London music agents and promoters eventuated in international concert tour management and working with international music promoters for many artists including Paul McCartney, The Rolling Stones, David Bowie, Pink Floyd, U2, Bruce Springsteen, Elton John, Deborah Harry, Iggy Pop and Nirvana.

David Chambers now based in Sydney has continued his musical ventures with the recording of both albums and singles in the recent years: Bouquet of Barbed Wire (2011), In The Next Life (2014) and Resolution (2017). Collaborating with producer singer-songwriter Cam Mackellar for the first two albums and self producing the latest release, David Chambers has been supported by a range of talented singers and players: Lisa Callingham, Madeleine Slattery, Kevin Elsey, Dave Wray, Brendan J. Beame, Josh Ahearn, Paul Jackson, Denny Ball, Luke Gerber, Anatoli Torjinski, Janine Simmel and long standing collaborator Ronnie “Wood” Harvey.

Recording recently at Sony Music Studios Sydney, David Chambers is continuing work on his next album of self penned songs.

Kenneth Nguyen is a partner in the global loans team in the Melbourne office. 

Kenneth specialises in: 
- corporate finance across industry sectors including agribusiness, corporate health, diversified industrials, consumer and services, and technology and telecommunications; 
- real estate finance (including residential and commercial construction financings, and acquisition and other investment financings); 
- leveraged and acquisition financing; and 
- loan portfolio sale transactions. 

His clients include Australian and international trading banks, investment banks and other financial institutions, alternative non-bank financiers (including mezzanine financiers), listed and institutional borrowers and insolvency practitioners.

general.headline: Consultant - Burgess Paluch Legal Recruitment
general.description:
Melissa is an outgoing and proactive consultant with local and international experience. Having worked as a lawyer in the US,  Melissa understands the legal market and delivers an incomparable recruitment and executive search service to her clients. She continues to be successful with private practice,  in-house corporate, in-house public sector, and lawyers in the Australian market and abroad.

Melissa double majored at University with a Bachelor in Political Science and History (Honours). Following her undergrad degree, she  worked on Capitol Hill in Washington D.C. assisting a Congressman in drafting legislation into law. Always having an interest in the law, she later attended Law School where she earned herself a Juris Doctorate and developed a keen interest in commercial litigation. 
 
Melissa utilises her legal skills, passion, and knowledge to specialise on legal roles from junior lawyers to equity partners and firm mergers. Her interpersonal skills combined with her professional execution and commitment to her clients allows her to be successful in placing lawyers in the right role. She has an internal belief that her placement can make a huge different in that individual’s career path.  Melissa does not believe in shortcuts, as there are none in the longevity of her career or the career of her placements. Building lasting relationships is the key to her success.

general.headline: Head of Shared Services, People & Culture at UnitingCare Queensland
general.description:
What difference do your people make to your company’s bottom line? Ask yourself….
■ Are employees inspired by leaders or instructed by managers? 
■ Are you an employer of choice or battling attrition? 
■ Is your culture fuelling your success or creating roadblocks?

And most of all, do you have a solid plan to turn your people into a highly effective competitive advantage?
 
The people side of your business isn’t the ‘soft stuff’. Your business, your reputation, and your brand depend on your people and their performance. People CAN do great things. But you’ve got to set the right vision, employ the right team, create the right environment, and the use the right systems to motivate them to be their best.

I’m an HR consultant who helps clients from startups to Top500 companies get where they need to go. First and foremost, I’m a business person, focussed on commercial outcomes and bringing ambitious HR strategy to life. 

I help you find what works for your unique challenges and your people. And I don’t just set HR strategy, I see it through with practical delivery. I’m about action, positive change, and getting the job done.

SERVICES
✓ HR strategy
✓ Performance & accountability
✓ Talent management
✓ Leadership development
✓ Enablement and empowerment
✓ Recruitment

Let’s have a chat about your HR challenges today:
✆ Call me on 0434 077 003
✉ Email me at PhariConsulting@gmail.com

jobs.jobTitle: Head of Shared Services, People & Culture

jobs.description:
I know how to get the most of people, and how you can do it too.  Having spent a good portion of my career at Virgin Australia, most recently as a general manager responsible for leadership, talent and development, I’ve worked with the best people, in one of THE best companies.  I now draw on this experience to partner with a range of clients. 

Typically, my clients seek HR advice and action when they’re facing challenges like:
✓ Acquiring a new business
✓ Overcoming high turnover or a spate of recent departures
✓ Transforming culture that’s hindering success
✓ Failing to meet targets, such as sales, customer satisfaction, productivity, or efficiency
✓ Motivating managers to step up and become leaders
In short, ANYWHERE you need people to make a difference. 

WHAT I DO
Here’s what we’ll look at as part of setting the right HR strategy for your business: 
1. Systems: The backbone of your HR strategy, such as performance management & recruitment.
2. Symbols: The non-verbal cues that embed or erode your culture. Think corner offices & carparks.
3. Behaviours: Having clear expectations, a common language, and motivating leaders to walk the talk and articulate what’s being done right and wrong.

HOW I WORK
I work hard to understand your business inside and out. Then I design a best-fit HR solution to suit your business, your people and your maturity level. And I help you deliver, with processes, documentation, a rollout plan, leadership education and on-call support. 

WHO I WORK WITH
I can help you with a single project, or become your go-to HR advisor. If you don’t have an HR manager, it can make sense to retain senior advice from an HR superstar who can make transformative change, vs hiring a full-time employee who is more likely to focus on incremental change.

My specialty is HR’s impact on customer service, with industry experience encompassing Professional Services, Banking, Technology, Government, Travel & Aviation.

Internally promoted to the role of General Manager during my tenure at Virgin Australia I was able to partner more strategically with the business to get outcomes.  Some of my achievements during this time included:
■ HR lead on Virgin’s rebrand, bringing the brand to life through all people systems, reinventing the company’s values and developing a Behaviours Guide. 
■ Led the design of a leadership effectiveness diagnostic tool.
■ HR lead on a full senior leadership restructure under a new CEO.
■ Led the roll out of a performance management framework.
■ Designed the principles of a new organisation architecture.
■ Introduced customised screening and video interviewing to the recruitment process.
■ Led the design and roll out of an engagement survey, including delivering results to the execution team and supporting senior leaders with action plans.
■ HR lead on a ‘Leading Through Transformational Change’ program to bring innovation to life.
■ Oversaw leadership development programs and talent forums to identify high potential individuals and position them for development opportunities. 
■ HR lead for the introduction of a new international airline and the Pacific Blue integration.
■ Maximising people effectiveness: including recruitment, on-boarding, talent management, performance management, and succession planning.
■ People & customer engagement: including a diversity and inclusion strategy, and community liaison.
■ Workplace relations: maintaining a stable industrial relations environment, including leading a team that successfully negotiated multiple EBAs without industrial action.
■ Embedding people systems: including Payroll, Staff & Duty Travel and Workers Compensation and coaching leaders to use systems effectively.

I provided HR advice and guidance to the Group Executive team and led teams of
      specialists to provide business partnering support to all business units. I was
      responsible for strategy, structure, performance and talent management,
      
      development, recruitment, workplace relations and EBA negotiation.  Over 

... See more

Before aviation, I worked in software. 
I was the HR lead in the Asia-Pacific for this North American ERP provider, supporting 12 countries including Australia, Hong Kong, Singapore, and the Philippines. I handled due diligence processes for acquisition targets and managed downsizing of the business by 25%.

I took on HR contracts in Melbourne and London for clients such as Honda, JP Morgan,
      
      and a joint venture IT project between 21 banks.

general.description:
I have been a specialist recruiter (both agency and in-house) for many years.  However, I do like variety and have a curiosity about different people, roles and industries which has seen me recruit a broad range of corporate and operational roles in a range of industries without any prior experience in that space.  I also have an innate passion for continuous improvement and have developed and delivered a number of initiatives in the past which have improved the attraction, engagement and retention rates of quality candidates for my employers and clients.  

I'm lucky after working in this area for some time I still love being an in-house talent specialist/recruitment specialist and ensuring I find people who not only have the right skills and experience but also the right cultural fit which makes them and the company a success match.  

I truly enjoy working with both clients and candidates.  I partner with my hiring managers/clients so I can advise them on the best recruitment strategy and range of on-line and people search sources to find THE right person they are searching for.  With candidates, they know I am genuine about their interests and career goals and I have successfully built strong and ongoing relationships even with those who were ultimately unsuccessful. 

To me, my focus is to create a WIN/WIN situation for all stakeholders.

SPECIALITIES:
Defence; ICT professionals - including project managers, business analysts, help desk engineers, systems analysts, enterprise architects, Agile consultants; Accountants, Aviation specialists and Managers and operational staff, learning and development and change management professionals as well as  fraud investigators, motor assessors and General Managers; cooks, chefs; and facility managers.

general.headline: Partner at Webb Henderson
general.description:
Tom specialises in the following:

•	litigation and dispute resolution;
•	competition law and consumer protection;
•	regulatory investigations and enforcement. 

Tom has acted for clients across a broad range of sectors including healthcare, pharmaceuticals, fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG), technology, manufacturing and telecommunications.

Tom is an experienced litigator, having acted in numerous proceedings in the High Court, the Federal Court and the Supreme Courts of all mainland Australian States in addition to the Australian Competition Tribunal and other State-based Tribunals. Tom has also acted in international arbitrations under both the UNCITRAL and ICC Rules.

Tom has particular experience acting in commercial contractual disputes, competition litigation actions conducted under Part IV of the Competition and Consumer Act (2010) (Cth) (CCA), including cartel conduct, misuse of market power and exclusive dealing, consumer law actions under the Australian Consumer Law (ACL), including misleading or deceptive and unconscionable conduct, shareholder disputes, claims against directors and related issues under the Corporations Act (2001) (Cth), negligence claims and in administrative law matters.

Tom has represented and advised both the ACCC and private clients in relation to competition and consumer law issues, including merger clearances, responding to s 155 notices and enforcement actions under Part IV of the CCA and the ACL.

Tom also regularly advises clients on all contentious and potentially contentious issues arising from the entry into, performance and termination of commercial transactions. Tom is also experienced in advising on broader risk management issues and has assisted clients in implementing risk avoidance strategies.

general.headline: Partner at Webb Henderson
general.description:
Ara has extensive experience advising clients in the telecoms, broadcasting and media sectors on a range of strategic corporate, commercial and regulatory projects.

Ara has been involved in some of the most high profile transactions in the telecoms space in Australia, the Asia-Pacific and Middle East. This has included projects on IoT and smart cities, super-fast broadband, structural separation, undersea cable systems, MVNOs, network sharing and interconnection, as well as competition law and regulatory clearance matters.

Ara’s practice currently has a strong focus on strategic transactions involving the development and implementation of IoT initiatives, including large scale smart city projects.

He also has extensive experience with corporate and commercial transactions to construct super-fast broadband networks and the design and implementation of regulatory models for wholesale access to these networks. This includes the development of wholesale contracting arrangements for duct, dark fibre and bitstream access in a number of countries.

Ara also frequently acts for online companies and broadcasting and media companies on a range of commercial, competition and regulatory matters.

Ara is recognised as a leading practitioner in International Who’s Who 2017 (TMT), Chambers Asia-Pacific 2017 and Best Lawyers 2017 (Telecommunications Law and Regulatory Practice).

Ara joined Webb Henderson in September 2009 and became a partner in April 2010. Prior to joining Webb Henderson, Ara practiced in the Competition and Regulation Group at Gilbert + Tobin.

jobs.description:
Some of Ara's recent experience includes advising:

* NBN Co, the entity building the National Broadband Network in Australia, on the development of its Special Access Undertaking, Wholesale Broadband Agreement and regulatory aspects of its A$9 billion transaction with Telstra

* SingTel, the leading telco in Singapore, on the rollout of the passive infrastructure of Singapore’s Next Generation Nationwide Broadband Network (NGNBN) and implementation of structural separation in relation to the passive layer of the NGNBN

* Commercial Radio Australia, the peak industry body for the commercial radio sector in Australia, on the launch and expansion of digital radio broadcast services in Australia

* SubPartners, a Superloop company, on the construction of the INDIGO cable system, a new high capacity undersea cable  connecting Singapore, Indonesia and Australia

* du, a leading telco in the UAE, on its strategic public private partnership with the Smart Dubai Office to develop and implement the Smart City Platform for the city of Dubai

* Ooredoo, the leading telco in Qatar, on a range of corporate, commercial and regulatory projects.
Competition and Regulation Group

general.school: University of Florida, Public Utility Research Center
general.description:
I'm a specialist lawyer working at the intersection of the law and next generation networks,
      technology and applications. I have focused on this intersection for 15 years. I'm fortunate
      
      to work on cutting edge projects for clients who are leaders in their fields.

jobs.description:
I advise telecommunications, media and technology clients regarding complex and strategic commercial contracts and regulatory issues. 

I have a strong technical background including a Computer Science degree. I also have extensive commercial experience, having completed in-house secondments with nbn and Telstra Media. 

My clients include nbn, Singtel, Spark and Ooredoo. I've previously worked with banks, IT outsourcers, mobile telecommunications companies and new and established media companies. Clients have included Qantas, Unisys, Optus and Telstra.

Prior to joining Webb Henderson, I was a lawyer in the IT, Communications and Media practice at Ashurst.

I advise telecommunications, media and technology clients regarding commercial
      contracts and regulatory issues.
      

    
      

    
      I have a strong technical background including a Computer Science degree

... See more
Telecommunications, media and technology lawyer

I was seconded to the Sales and Communications team within the legal group at NBN Co. Working with the Products, Operations, Sales and Marketing, this role had it all. And at a key time for the national broadband builder, as it establishes everything from its operational systems, to the products it's delivering, the network it's rolling out and the customer relationships it's establishing with Australia's retail telecommunications and Internet service providers.

While at Blake Dawson, I was in the IT, Communications and Media team.

During my 5+ years in the team I assisted on a range of commercial contracts, from IT outsourcing to e-commerce terms. I acted for telecommunications companies, outsourcers, cross-border consumer sales sites, large enterprises and public bodies.

My advice and assistance to clients required an excellent understanding of black-letter law, including core contract law issues such as the principles of novation, principal-agent arrangements, liability principles (including indemnities) and legislative regimes such as privacy. The key value for clients, however, was the ability to work with the client to apply these skills and knowledge to the specific business context facing the client.

I also advised and presented on social media issues, helping clients to understand how to grasp the opportunities while understanding and preparing for the risks.

During 18 months at Telstra Media, I assisted on the creation of Telstra's next-generation IP-based set-top box and significant developments in its internet media strategy.

I worked on technology contracts with equipment and service suppliers, content contracts with movie and TV show licensors and advertising / marketing related contracts across IPTV, web and mobile platforms.

I also worked on customer-facing terms and advised on consumer protection as it applied to technology and media products and services.
